text:
This is one of my favorite easy "busy-day" crockpot recipes.  I make it Weight Watchers friendly by omitting the butter, adding mushrooms, and 1/2 cup of water, and substituting FF cream cheese and Reduced Fat soup. I serve it over whole wheat noodles or brown rice.  Only 5 points per serving plus the points for the noodles or rice.

text:
This turned out to be a great recipe -- whole family enjoyed it. I, like many other reviewers, was a bit skeptical of combining the chicken w/nothing more than 1/8 c margerine and the dry salad dressing mix, but figured there must be a reason or Judi would not have submitted it this way, so I resisted the urge to add the canned soup in the beginning. I did add a splash of red wine that I had on hand, but other than that, there was very little liquid. Also used Good Seasons Mild Italian dressing mix, since my kids don't like highly spiced food. I turned the crockpot on low and cooked for about 7+ hours, and of course the house smelled incredible. The chicken chunks were golden brown and had a roasted taste and appearance, something that wouldn't have occurred had I added the soup at the beginning. I then added a can of reduced fat cream of chick soup and a brick of red. fat cream cheese. Plopped the brick in whole, covered, then stirred after it had softened. Turned out so delicious, and in no way reduced fat tasting! My 6-year old daughter ate so many "appetizer bites" out of the pot, she was full by dinner time! Very creamy and rich tasting, and the dressing mix provides just the right amount of seasoning. We served over noodles -- delicious! Very easy, tasty recipe -- and seems "fancy" enough for company. Putting this in my Favorites folder.

text:
This is the best recipe EVER!!  I can't tell you how thrilled I was with how it turned out.  I cut down the chicken to 2 very large chicken breasts because my crock pot is only 1 1/2 quarts and it's just me eating (I don't like tons of leftovers), but I left all the other amounts for the sauce the same.  I cooked the soup (Campbell's 98% Fat Free), margarine and dressing mix plus 1/4 cup of white wine with the chicken from the beginning, then added 4 tablespoons of 1/3 less fat cream cheese (Neufchatel cheese) and about half a cup of fat free cream cheese.  It was fabulous- EXACTLY like Angel Chicken Pasta on this web site, which I love and is my favorite recipe in the world, only less fat, much, much less preparation, and fewer dishes that don't have anything burned or stuck on!  I think I'll be making this often now, thank you so much, Judi!  Update a while later: this is also awesome with pork chops instead of chicken and I use no butter and half the cream cheese.

text:
This was the most delicious dinner.  I used frozen chicken breasts straight from the freezer to the pot and followed advice from other reviewers: Skipped the margarine, used half of 0.7 oz pkg Italian dressing mix (will use even less next time), 1 can Healthy Request Crm of Chicken soup and 1 can Healthy Request Crm of Mushrom soup thinned with about 3/4 c. milk.  I let it cook for about five hours until it was moist and tender, falling apart.  Shredded the chicken and then I added 4 oz. 1/3 less-fat cream cheese and about 1/2 c. of sour cream.  I let it cook in the crockpot for another 45 minutes to let the flavors blend.  Served it over whole wheat egg noodles and it was heavenly.

Typically, I make the recipe exactly as written the first time, but I didn't have any cream of chicken soup ... so I used cream of mushroom - YUM!  My picky, picky Hubby who doesn't like "white" foods, loved this.  My 5-year-old daughter gave it two thumbs and a big toe up! :-)  I'm sure no one will read this review, but I wanted to put it out there anyway ... definitely shred the chicken, then there isn't too much sauce and don't be afraid to thin it with some milk.  Delicious!  THANK YOU!

text:
This was FABULOUS!!!!  I was in a dinner slump and just joined allrecipes a few days ago.  Picked out this recipe after reading all the reviews.  I did alter the recipe somewhat after reading the reviews--I put the 98% fat free cream of chicken soup, the butter (yes, I used butter!), 1/2 of the Italian dressing mix packet, 1/4 cup white cooking wine and 1/4 cup chicken broth (I used Herb Ox) in the crock pot and mixed it up.  I threw in the frozen chicken breasts and cooked on low for 5 hours.  I then shredded the chicken in the crock pot, added softened 4 oz. Neufchatel cheese, and about 1/3 cup of fat free sour cream.  It cooked for half an hour on high.  When I tasted it, I thought it tasted almost exactly like a pasta dish I always get at the local Italian Restaurant, minus the spiciness.  To add a little kick, I threw in some chilipiquin peppers that are growing in my back yard.  Served it over wheat egg noodles.  EVERYONE in the family loved it!!!!!!  THANK YOU!

This recipe is excellent just the way it is. I always go by the recipe first and rate it. There is no need to add the soup first. The margarine and juices from the chicken are plenty as it is. I get a bit bummed to see people rate these recipes a 5 star but yet there are two paragraphs to how they alter it. Therefore it really is no longer "this" recipe. I can see changing it to less fat or sodium.

text:
This was delicious, although I made some variations based on the similar Slow Cooker Beef Stroganoff (which I loved) on this site.  I added a chopped onion, used only half of the Italian dressing mix packet (0.7 oz.), healthy choice cream of chicken soup, and only half of the cream cheese.  I also added about 1/4 cup of milk.  These changes made the end result less thick, caloric, and salty.  It was wonderful!

text:
Oh, this was good.  All 3 kids AND the husband loved it, which says it all. I liked that it was so easy to prepare.  I threw in 4 large frozen chicken breasts, the can of soup (low fat), the margarine, some white wine, and a .6 oz package of Tastefully Simple Garlic Garlic dip mix (because I didn't have the Italian dsg. mix and I REALLY wanted to try this recipe).  Left it on low all day, then shredded the chicken and added about 2/3 package of low fat cream cheese (that I melted in the microwave with some milk) about 30 minutes before serving.  Served it over brown rice and the kids ate it all up and didn't even realize they were eating brown rice!  The one thing is that it doesn't make much sauce, so if you like things saucier, add some more liquid to it.  We'll definitely keep this one in the dinner rotation!

text:
AMAZING!  I made a few simple changes, leaving all the ingredients the same.  I brushed the frozen breasts with the melted butter and Italian seasoning (I stirred them together before coating).  I also added the soup at this time so it would not dry out the chicken during cooking.  After 5 hours I took out the chicken and shredded it (extremely moist!) then added in the cream cheese and turned crockpot down to warm to heat through.  It was just wonderful, great flavor!  May I suggest the best thing ever??  CROCK POT LINERS!  No sticking to the pot and majorly quick clean up!  Pull it out of the crock pot and toss in the trash, boom... you are done with cleanup!! They are just the best and made this recipe even better... :O)

text:
This recipe was a nice change of pace from other crock pot recipes. The flavor was excellent and the whole family loved it.  I think that one packet of Italian dressing mix was just the right amount of flavor, and it wasn't too salty.  After reading other reviews about using only 1/2 of a packet, I was a little worried it would be too strong as I'm a little sensitive to salt.  I wouldn't recommend cutting it back at all.  It was perfect just the way it is.  I did use low fat cream cheese, and fat-free cream of chicken soup and it turned out wonderful.  Crock pot recipes are usually very easy, but this one was unbelievably easy!  I'll be using this one again for sure!

There are even some other additions you could consider:  Bacon, mushrooms, onions, white wine or even a can of green chilies.  Hard to believe that this wonderful dish is both Weight Watchers AND Atkins friendly.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
I made this yesterday and admit I used it as a base start. I have a habit of looking at the recipes and reading the reviews of others before deciding whether to try one or not!  I am so glad this one made it to my table! I used 7 chicken thighs as that was what I had on hand. We try to watch our salt intake and after coating the thighs with the dry mix remembered other reviewers said it was too salty so I rinsed off some of the Italian dressing mix off the thighs.  Next time I will just use ½ a pack so I will not waste it. After it had cooked for 7 hours I drained the juices out of the crock pot & de-boned and shredded the chicken.  Pre-heated the cream cheese & soup mix in a sauce pan with about 1/4 cup of white wine, and instead of sour cream used 4 heaping tablespoons of plain yogurt. When it was hot & no longer lumpy I then mixed it in the chicken added fresh sautéed mushrooms and left it in the crock pot for another hour. Hubby had his on wide egg noodles; I had mine on white rice. Served it with a side salad. It was awesome! I could not believe how easy it was to prepare. I will be making this again!  I will give this 4 stars as I believe that had it been made as it was written it would have been very good but feel that the simple additions is what made it so WONDERFUL!***We ate the left overs for diner last night and it was even better! OMG!!! I am soooo looking forward to making this again!

text:
Awesome!  Try it with chive and onion cream cheese, the flavor is amazing.*  I cooked the chicken for only 3 hours (stirring occasionally) on low before adding soup and cream cheese and it was done, very tender and delicious.  I had no cream of chix soup so I made a small batch: Melt 2 Tbs unsalted butter over med heat, add 2 Tbs flour and stir until well mixed.  Add one cup of milk and stir until it starts to bubble.  Add 1 to 1 1/2 tsp chicken bouillon (1 tsp = 1 cube) and mix well. Reduce heat and simmer for a few minutes before adding to chicken.  Add a little more milk if needed. Perfect for 3 large or 4 med boneless chicken breasts.  *I use only half a package of italian dressing mix if I use the seasoned cream cheese.

TURBOSAUR

city:

country:
None
text:
Its awesome, but its not stroganoff.  It does come out REALLY thick and kinda salty. I love it.  If you dont like high salt content, use low sodium soups, if its too thick, add some water or chicken broth.    Its a great recipe, but if you're looking for a classic stroganoff taste this doesn't have it.  Try this modification.  Add 2-3 bay leaves to the chicken and butter (I don't do margarine) and salad dressing at the start.  Once the chicken is cooked, add 1/4 cup sherry, let the booze cook off for about 15 minutes, then throw in 1/2 the cream cheese, 8oz of sour cream, and a pan full of sauted mushrooms. Skipped the condensed soup. I also like to water it down a bit with  of low sodium chicken stock.  Then it really tastes like stroganoff, although the original recipe is still yummy goodness.  I noticed some people putting in wine.  When cooking with cream sauces don't ever use white wine- its way too acidic and citrusy for a cream sauce.  Use sherry or chicken broth if you feel it needs extra liquid and water won't cut it.

city:

text:
I have made this before just following the recipe and it is great but I like a bit more flavor so my favorite way to do this is to put 4 chicken breasts (straight from freezer) in the crock pot along with 1/5 a cup of melted butter, 1 full pack of zesty italian spices and a few splashes of white wine. I make sure both sides of chicken are coated in seasoning and butter before I close up the pot on low for 7 hours. After the 7 hours on low I add frozen peas (1/3 a bag), mushrooms (3/4 can), 1 can condensed cream of chicken and here's the key: 1 container of cooking cream(Philadelphia, the new cooking cream cheeses, found next to the cream chewed) I use the Italian cheese and herbs. It really adds a punch to this dish. I let this cook for 45 min on low and serve over egg noodles. DELISH!!!!!!

I thought this was a good recipe. I made it last night and I only made a couple of additions. I added fresh mushrooms and a 1/2 c of dry white wine at the beginning.Some hints...I softened the margarine before I mixed it in with the dressing mix..this helped coat the chicken better. Then, when it was time to stir in the cream cheese and soup, I softened the cream cheese in the microwave first and then mixed with the soup before I added to the crock pot..  I also used low fat cream of chicken soup and low fat cream cheese and it still was excellent-and very rich!Yum!

Display Name:
Dawn Duckett

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe gets 10 stars for "EASY".  And, very good.  I followed the recipe just as written, with one exception; I did not cut up my chicken breasts before cooking.  I used the frozen ones, and just let them thaw in the refrigerator over night.  I resisted the urge to add any liquid and was very surprised that there was plently of liquid in the pot at the end of 6 1/2 hours of slow cooking on low.  The 2 tablespoons of margarine (not butter) and the juices from the chicken were sufficient to produce all the liquid needed.  I sprinkled the entire package of dressing mix over the chicken and margarine and put the lid on.  I had to cook a little longer because we were not home and got home a little later than I expected, but I could not tell that the extra 1/2 hour cooking time effected it at all.  When I poked the chicken with a fork, it fell apart and basically shredded on it on with only a few twists of the fork.  I put the entire block of cream cheese in the microwave for 30 seconds to soften it before I mixed it with the soup.  I then added it to the chicken and let it cook on low while I cooked some wide egg noodles to go with the stroganoff.  By the time the noodles were done, the stroganoff was ready to serve over the noodles.  I severed with some steamed green peas, which my daughter mixed with her stroganoff and noodles and said it was really good.  (I might mix the peas in with the stroganoff next time.)  We ate this with some Pillsbury Place and Bake Crescent Round

text:
This recipe is fabulous! It is great comfort food for a cold day. I have made this recipe on several occasions and my entire family, picky eaters and all ate it up! I make it with fat-free cream cheese and 98% fat free cream of chicken soup. It brings the calories down to less than 300, the fat to about 6g, the sat fat to 1.5g and the cholesterol to about 64mg per serving. I also add a little water to make it a more "servable" consistency. I also, on occasion when pressed for time, make it on the stovetop and it turns out great every time. Love it!

text:
The ONLY reason I am rating this as a 4 is that I found that 5-6 hours on low for the cubed chicken was way too long.  I added the soup and cream cheese after 4 hours, and then kept it on warm for an hour until everything else was ready, and it was just fine.  I was prepared to add sour cream to give it that "stroganoff" flavor, but when I tasted the sauce at the end, I was amazed at how much like a stroganoff sauce it tasted, so I nixed the sour cream (yeah - fewer calories!).  This is a definite keeper in our house.  Thank you Judi Ann.

text:
My family LOVES this recipe.  What I've learned from making this several times is that if you will be home in 5-6 hours, follow the recipe exactly.  If you are going to be gone longer, then it is best to add the soup in the morning unless you use frozen chicken breasts which will obviously take longer to cook.  I had a long day at work and left the thawed chicken breasts on low for 7 hours and they began to get brown.  This did not affect the taste of the recipe, however.  I have also used a packet of ranch dressing which I had on hand, rather than the Italian. This is simple and delicious every time!

This was so easy and tasty!  I had 5 large chicken breasts, so I used 2 pkgs of dressing mix and doubled all the other ingredients.  I'm glad I did since we like a good bit of sauce.    My husband picked up the 98% fat free cream of soups (1 chicken/1 mushroom) by mistake, and I didn't realize it til I actually made the meal.  I was worried it might compromise the texture or flavor of the sauce, but it was delicious!  I softened the cream cheese and mixed it well with the soups before adding it to the slow cooker.  I did need to thin the sauce a bit, as others mentioned, so I used 2 soup cans of water and 2 bouillon cubes. text:
This is the 2nd time I've made this; the last time I made it by another recipe I found on Pinterst, and it seemed bland.  This time, I put my whole skinless, boneless breasts in the crockpot with the butter (margarine is not food!) and Italian dressing and got it going.  I also doubled it and added a third pack of Italian dressing.  After 3 or 4 hours (I had it on high), I put the cream cheese on top since I was leaving home for about 2 hours; turned it on low.  When I came home, I added the chicken soup, took the breasts out so I could stir the sauce together well, then pulled the chicken into hunks and tasted.  I added some pepper and dried parsley and some additional garlic (cloves, minced in the beginning, and granulated garlic).  We didn't find it salty; if you taste the sauce alone, without the chicken and egg noodles, it seems a little tangy, I think from the dried Italian dressing.  This time we LOVED it.  Each person's taste is different, I'd say cook as directed, then taste.  Like us, you may actually need a little salt, pepper, etc.

I made this the other night for a friend and my nieces (ages 10 and 14).  My nieces can be VERY picky so I was careful to choose something to make that I thought might please their palates.  Well--winner, winner, chicken dinner!  This was a huge hit with everybody!  I fatally cracked my slow cooker insert (long story) so I wound up cooking this in a large pot on the stove, making the necessary timing and temp adjustments (which I successfully guessed at!). The only hard part (not really) was cubing all that chicken which I tackled when the breasts were still slightly frozen.  
I served this over cooked egg noodles and had delicious Jersey produce as the sides: corn on the cob and cucumber & tomato salad.  I served cubed fresh watermelon for dessert.  Did I mention zucchini bread?!  My nieces have requested I make this chicken recipe again very soon!

What I loved the most about this recipe was the simplicity! I served the stroganoff with brown rice--so yummy!

text:
I tried this for the first time yesterday.  The hub & I found it quite tasty, and it was so easy.  I cut both chicken breasts and thighs into chunks (bigger than cubes) and placed them, along with some diced onion in the slow cooker.  I melted the required amount of butter (instead of margarine) and mixed the dry italian dressing into it, then poured it over the chicken pieces.  I also added 1/2 cup of white wine.  I started cooking it on low, at 1:30 in the afternoon and then went about my day.  At 7:00, I added the cream cheese and cream of chicken soup, and started cooking extra wide egg noodles.  By, 7:30, everything was ready, so I mixed up the noodles & chicken sauce, heated up some garlic bread, and dinner was served.  Next time, I might add some green chilies to give it a little zip!!

text:
We LOVED it!!  Okay, okay I changed it up a bit after reading the reviews.  I put the chicken in whole, melted the butter and added the italian seasoning.  Placed it in the crockpot stirred and made sure every piece of chicken was well coated with the butter/italian season mixture.  Cooked on low for 4 hours.  Shredded the chicken, mixed the cream cheese and I used cream of mushroom soup--no reason other than I wanted to--, put in fresh mushrooms and let cook on low for another 30 min.  The sauce did not look like enough liquid for the 4 of us so I added 1 1/4 cup heavy cream, grated 1/4 cup parmesean cheese and another tablespoon of butter.  Served over linguine with garlic bread and called it CHICKEN ALFREDO. YUM, YUM, YUM. and Oh so easy.  Definitealy a keeper.

text:
I made this last night and we loved it.  I had 4 large frozen blsl chicken breasts, and I knew I would be gone all day, so I put them in the crock pot w/ 2 cans of cream of chicken soup, about 1/2 a cup of italian dressing (I didn't have any dry packet mixes on hand), garlic powder, onion powder, parsley, italian seasonings, (didn't measure any), and butter (I don't usually have margarine), cooked on low 9 hours (b/c that is how long I am away from the house, and I don't have a timer...darn it!), I removed the chicken so I wouldn't overcook it and added the low fat cream cheese, and turned the heat up to high and let it melt for about an hour.  Added the chicken back in (which we kept whole) and turned to keep warm just long enough to warm the chicken back up.  Served with rice, green beans and garlic and herb biscuits!  YUMMY!  Will make this again for sure!

I've been making a variation of this recipe for years that's even easier: i omit the margarine, and put all other ingredients in the crockpot together on low(i use frozen chicken breasts). When I get home from work, I'll stir it up (and cut up the chicken breasts), then serve over egg noodles.

text:
My husband and I loved this.  Based on other reviews, here are the tweaks I made.  Used butter instead of margarine, only half of the dry Italian mix, and only half of the cream cheese.  I added some pepper, lemon pepper, parsley, garlic powder, and Italian seasoning to make up for not using all of the dry Italian mix.  Some othe other reviews said that it was too salty so that is why I didn't use it all.  I added some sauteed onions at the end just to kick it up a notch!  I tossed the egg noodles in the crock pot (about 2/3 of a bag) when it was ready to serve.  For step one, I melted the butter and combined the Italian mix before putting the chicken in.  For step two, I cooked it for about an hour.  We will definitely make this again.  My husband and I both rated this about 8 out of 10 which is very high on our scale!

text:
This was delicious! Everyone in my family loved it and that makes it a winner in my book! The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is because I tweaked it a bit: used 1/4 cup bottled italian dressing instead of the margerine/dressing mix, added 1/2 t garlic powder (we love garlic at my house) & a splash of white wine, cooked on high for 3 hours, then added the soup, 4 oz. cream cheese, 1/2 cup sour cream, 3/4 cup chicken broth, dash of black pepper and paprika, cooked on low for another 45 minutes and served it over rice (though I think egg noodles would have been even better). The chicken was "melt in your mouth" yummy!

text:
This was so good!  It didn't take near the 7 hours.  I used frozen flat chicken breast.  I followed the Weight Watcher's way from a previous review with lots of mushrooms, 8 oz Fat Free cheese, 1 can 98% FF Cream of Chicken, and 1/4 cup of FF sour cream right at the end.  Instead of the italian dressing packet I used 1/2 cup of FF Italian Dressing.  I Cooked the Chicken with the Ialian Dressing and a splash of water for about 2 hours on high, then added the mixture of Cream of Chicken, mushrooms, and cream cheese.  cooked for another hour on low, added the sour cream and cooked for another 1/2 hour on low.  This is a perfect dish for a saturday when you are home to mess with it but busy cleaning and waht not.  LOVED  it, will definately make again.

Mmmm, the perfect comfort food.  I added a splash of dry white wine in the beginning with the chicken, butter, and seasoning packet.  Don't believe other reviewers when they say the whole packet is too much seasoning...it is the perfect amount. text:
Delicious recipe, especially for a crowd with a wide variety of tastes! (Though it is a bit salty. Using Healthy Request soup helps.)  I have made this countless times. Most recently I used the Italian Dressing Mix homemade (minus salt) from this site. I also substituted the soup with evaporated milk mixed with a heaping Tbsp. cornstarch and two tsp. chicken base. To the original recipe I always add fresh sliced mushrooms. Garlic added is great too. Served with steamed fresh carrots and broccoli, and herb bread. I think the addition of chopped red pepper or pimiento would be wonderful for taste and contrast. I also thought this dish was great with the sauce cooked longer (less cooking time for chicken, more time with sauce). And if I miss the slow cooker deadline, I use the stove!!

This was a very quick and easy recipe.  I used the recommended 1/2 pkg of italian dressing, low-salt butter and mixed it in with fresh mushrooms, 1/2 orange pepper, full medium sized green pepper, and a medium sized onion.  I sprinkled it with both black pepper and hot chiles for a bit of a bite.  After slow cooking for 4 1/2 hours I added the cream cheese (light) as well as the Campbells cream of chicken soup (low fat) and 2 TBSP of sour cream.  It turned out amazing!  Placed it on a bed of rice and my girlfriend and I were in heaven.  A rich meal, not salty at all.  Next time I will try it with Bell Peppers or Habanero peppers.

text:
You CAN put just the chicken in the slow cooker for hours. (With the little bit of butter and seasoning, as the recipe says.) It was fine and did not dry out, the natural juices of the chicken came out and kept it moist. I even left it for longer, over 9 hours, since I left it while I went to work.
I also was worried the Italian dressing would give it the wrong flavor (I was thinking it would be basil and oregano flavors like spaghetti sauce), but not at all, it was a nice herb mix.  Although not the same flavor as beef stroganoff.  I've never heard of chicken stroganoff, so not sure what it's supposed to taste like.  But found this recipe to be a nice creamy, midly herbed chicken flavor.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I thought this recipe tasted GREAT with some modifications. I substituted: Health Valley brand low sodium, all natural cream of chicken soup, 2 bricks Neufchatel (1/3 less fat) cream cheese, homemade Italian seasoning for the Italian salad dressing mix, and unsalted butter for the margarine called for. At the start, to the chicken and butter I added 1/2 cup low sodium chicken broth, & 1 cup white wine.  Part of the way through the cooking processes I added chopped, fresh green beans and 1/2 diced red bell pepper. Increased the seasoning a little bit with a few drops of low sodium Worcestershire Sauce and a couple sprinkles of Frank's Red Hot. The chicken only needed 4 hours on low to cook, after which I added the cream cheese and cooked to melt. (I needed more cream cheese than called for because I had added too much liquid at the start). At the very end, added 1/4 cup of heavy cream. Very happy with the flavor, consistency and sodium level, but I'm not sure why my cubed chicken breasts seemed tough. Overall, when served on egg noodles, rice or quinoa this was a great 1-dish meal.

Wow what a delight, no need for
any extra liquid in the beginning. Cooked on hi for the first 3 hours & low for another 2 hrs. I also added 1/2 cup of milk and a 1/4 cup chicken broth. this was for my tastes, not as thick that way, and goes further for a family of 4! Wonderful dish.

Display Name:
Misa925

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good, not exceptional, 3 stars for flavor but added one star because it's incredibly easy to make. Many of the negative reviews said it was way too salty, note that this recipe calls for the tiny .7 oz dressing packet! The ones I buy are 1.3 oz packets so I weighed out my dressing mix & used the .7 oz called for & didn't find it too salty, just right for our tastes. Also some negative reviews said the chicken was too dry, well that can depend on size of chicken breasts used & size of crock pot. I have a large 6 qt crock pot & used medium sized breasts so most of my chicken sat directly on the bottom of the pot, & I noticed about 2 hours in that the chicken was already cooked through. Since I planned on 5 1/2 hours until dinner I turned it down to "warm" temp for the next 3 hours & the chicken turned out just right. The gravy was a bit thick, I think if served with just-drained-pasta it would have been okay but because I was serving with rice I wanted it thinner so it would drip down into the rice a bit more so I added a bit of milk, maybe 1/4 cup. I used the condensed cream of chicken soup called for in the recipe, which made it turn out a pale whipped-butter-yellow, which was kind of weird for a sauce, & I think it would be better with the addition of garlic, so I may try this recipe again using condensed cream of mushroom with roasted garlic soup. This would make for a different flavor that I think we'd like more, the color would be more appetizing.

text:
I made this for supper tonight, and like a couple other reviewers said was concerned about the lack of liquid but also resisted the urge to dump everything in at the beginning. I used 3 medium sized boneless breasts. Didn't have the dry Italian dressing mix, so used Lipton's Garlic & Herb soup mix. Cooked on low for about 6-1/2 hrs, and when I got home added the cream cheese & soup, put the lid back on while I put noodles on to boil. Then shredded the chicken right in the pot like another reviewer suggested.  It is a bit too thick for my liking, so I did add about 1/4 cup of chicken broth.  This is definitely an awesome slow cooker recipe.  It wasn't quite as flavorful as I was hoping, but that could be the change in seasoning.  I still gave it 5 stars though, because my 17 year old picky daughter loved it and had 2nd's...she rarely has 2nd's at home.  That's an accomplishment right there! :)  Thank you for sharing this simple but wonderful recipe!!

text:
Absolutely the best-tasting Chicken Stroganoff ever!  My husband loves this dish.  I doubled it and we ate it all within a few days.  The cream cheese takes a while to melt properly so I had to cook it a little bit longer.  And due to the extra salt in the salad dressing mix and canned soup, you do not need to salt this at all.  We had it over egg noodles.  It's such a simple, quick dish, no chopping veggies or pre-cooking meat, just drop in crock pot, go about your daily activites, and come home to a wonderful aroma and delicious dinner!  We will definitely make this dish over and over again.  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
I was looking for an easy chicken slow cooker recipe this was a great one!  My husband wasn't feeling well so I actually omitted the soup/cream cheese mixture from the crock pot part and did that on the stovetop for myself.  So the only things in the crock pot were the butter, chicken breasts, some sliced baby portabella mushrooms and the italian seasoning.  And I have to say WOW!  This dish is so flavorful without the sauce that we have been making it every week.  The chicken and mushrooms make a really nice broth to pour over egg noodles.  I did try the sauce the first time but honestly I liked it better without!  There isn't anything wrong with the sauce - it was just that the flavor of the chicken without it was so fantastic I didn't want to add anything to it!  I read the reviews and agreed that the butter makes a nice coating and since I always toss in fresh mushrooms, it adds a richness to the flavors - and sometimes I use only half the envelope of seasoning because it can be a bit overwhelming.  This is one of our new favorites.

I used 1/2 c. white wine with the 2 tbsp. butter and dressing mix with my frozen chicken breasts on low for 5 hours... chicken was pretty tender... I shredded the chicken then adding the soup and one cup of milk with the cream cheese and turned on high for a little over an hour. After the hour I whisked the mixture .. to mix the cream cheese because of chunks.... Added sliced mushrooms that I sauted in butter and olive oil. I cooked egg noodles poured the chicken mixture on top... topping it with grated parmesan cheese... YUMMY!  Will keep this recipe for sure!!!!!!

text:
A fast-cooker version.  I put in 8 frozen chicken breast tenders with the butter and 1/2 package of dressing mix in my crock-pot on HIGH for 1 hour. The house smelled amazing after just a few minutes.  After an hour I checked the chicken and it was cooked to perfection. I shredded it and added the soup and cream cheese. Covered and let sit still on HIGH for 20 minutes.  Meanwhile I sauteed mushrooms and an onion, cooked egg noodles, and microwaved a bag of Steamable Peas.   Then added the sauteed mushrooms and onions, peas and noodles to the crock pot. The sauce was too thick so I thinned it out with milk and pasta water. I also added about a 1/3 c of sour cream and a dash of pepper.  Yum! Next time I'll chop the chicken instead of shredding it and double the recipe.

This is a very tasty recipe. The first time I made this i followed the recipe exactly, and i found my chicken to be a little on the dry side(i did put my chicken in thawed). The second time i made it i had to put the chicken in frozen and added the can of cream of chicken soup. After about 5 hours cut the chicken up and added half a brick of creamcheese and half a cup of sour cream, wow what a difference, the chicken was so tender and the flavour was amazing, i think putting the chicken in frozen is what made it so much better the second time. I served over egg noodles with garlic bread, my family loved it! I will making this alot.

I've made this once and that was off the recommendation from my mother in law, we added a clove of crushed garlic, about 1/2 cup white wine and about 1 cup of mushrooms.  The only thing I found was that you need to chop the chicken up in BIG pieces otherwise the chicken just falls apart when it's chopped small.  So make them big chunks otherwise you really would have a sauce and not a chicken with sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe paired with rice makes a fantastic one-dish meal!  I followed the recipe almost as written, with a few changes: did not cube chicken (for sake of simplicity), only used 1/2 package of cream cheese, added 1/4 cup fat free sour cream, added 1 can of peas (drained).  Also, I substituted low-fat or fat-free products where possible, as the extra calories are unnecessary and make no difference to the final product.
I threw in 4 (or 5?) large chicken breast halves, margarine and 1 package of mix.  Cooked on low for an entire day (8 AM to 5 PM) while at work, came home and shredded the chicken with two forks and then added the remaining ingredients.  Then cooked on high for 20 minutes and then stirred and kept cooking on high for another 15-20 minutes.  Meanwhile, rice was cooked in a rice cooker.  So basically, the entire meal was ready to be eaten within 40 minutes of coming home!  Awesome and will definitely make again for me and my boyfriend (who could "eat it everyday").  Only change I would make is perhaps use 1/2 to 3/4 of a packet of salad dressing mix to reduce the sodium level.

text:
Very easy and kids friendly.
I used whole chicken ( the only thing I had on hand) 2 pkgs of dry dressing mix, 2 cream of mushroom soup, 4 oz of cream cheese and 1 cup of sour cream.For start, I added big chunks of carrots, red onion and mushrooms at bottom of pot, added butter and dry mix, and layed chicken on top. After 6 hours, I put in rest of soups,sour cream and cream cheese and continued on low for 1/2 hour more, then added a whole pkg of spagettini broken into 3, mixed all and left to cook for another 1/2 hour. It absorbed the liquids and made it into a thick stew. I served with thick crusty bread with butter on top. Kids loved it and so did DH. will make it again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5875217.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We tried this yesterday and it tasted pretty good.  I added a couple ingredients though because it looked to have a really thick/pasty consistency.  I mixed the soup and cream cheese in a bowl and put it in the microwave for about two minutes (stirring about every thirty seconds), then poured it in the crockpot.  Because this mixture is rather thick, I also added 1 cup of water and 1 cup of chicken broth, then stirred evenly.  The chicken was really tender and tasted great.  The only other change I might suggest was also in another review.  Depending on your personal preference, two packets of the italian seasoning may make it taste a little too salty, so only use one packet instead of two.  Overall, it's easy and taste good.

I did use a packet of regular Italian dressing and next time I may try it with the zesty Italian and see how that is.

My family loved this.  I used chicken thighs because my husband hates white meat.  I also used real butter and added some Pasta Sprinkle from Penzey's Spices in with the Italian Dressing mix.  The thighs cooked for 6 hours and then I cooked the cream cheese and soup in (with a can of mushrooms) while I made the egg noodles to serve it with.  Great reviews at the table!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I've made this twice now, and I'm amazed at the simplicity and the great flavor this recipe brings! The only addition I make is a can of cream of mushroom soup, as well as the cream of chicken. I also let the chicken cook in the soups for four hours on the low setting, and add the cream cheese the last half hour of cooking. Cheap, easy, and literally takes 3 mins to throw in the crock pot!

text:
Yummy & easy peasy!  
I used four frozen chicken breasts, threw them in whole and forgot the butter (I don't use margarine).  Added the butter after about three hours, when I realized it, so a couple end pieces were a little burnt.  I cooked on low for six hours (due to the chicken being frozen) then added the soup & cc.  
Served over whole wheat wide egg noodles and it was so fantastic!  
My house did not smell good as the chicken was cooking, but I think it might have been because there was no oils in the pot for the first few hours.  So that probably was my fault!

None
text:
I have made this so many times, and it is excellent! It reheats very well too. Learning that so little butter is all the moisture you need to cook meat in a slow cooker has been a revelation to me. Chicken with just a couple pats of butter, salt and pepper in the slow cooker is now THE way I make shredded chicken for any recipe I need. When I want different flavors, I try different dry mixes including dry pesto sauce mix and my favorite, Hidden Valley Ranch dry dressing mix. I love that you can put pre-cleaned frozen meat in and it works just as well.

text:
I really liked this recipe.  It was total comfort food.  I added a splash of white wine in with the combination of chicken breast and thighs, butter, and italian seasoning mix.  Then with about 2 hours to go, I added 8 oz. of neufchatel/lowfat cream cheese, low sodium cream of chicken soup, and a can of sliced mushrooms, because stroganoff has to have mushrooms.  I continued to cook on LOW.  I served this over whole wheat penne pasta.  Delicious!

This is just fantastic!!  I used frozen chicken breast tenderloins.  I added 1 can each of the cream of chicken and cream of mushroom soup. I added everything all at once except for the cream cheese. text:
I followed this recipe exactly, except when i put the chicken, butter, and dry dressing in, i added about a half cup of white wine just because other cooks suggested it, and i was afraid the chicken would dry out or burn without enough liquid in the pot.  I also used regular cream of chicken instead of condensed, and it was fine. Overall this recipe is great for a quick dinner, and is very flexible (be great with peas, or tri colored frozen peppers or even fresh steamed broccoli)  the only downfall is that it isnt exactly the healthiest of recipes, but that can be fixed with low fat ingredients possibly. Its also very tasty and yummy and quick and kids will love!  We put it over egg noddles and had it with steamed vegetables.   Thx!

Used 2 seasoned chicken breasts, browned them (till no longer pink)in oil first. Added to slow cooker (soup & Italian seasoning, fried onions). Cooked on high for 1 hour, then turned to low. Added 1/2 cream cheese & 1/2 c. monterey jack cheese. Cooked addt'l 1/2 hour. Perfect for 2, and cut cook time way down.

text:
Very good start to a great recipe!  After reading most of the reviews, I used only half a packet of the dressing mix, a can of soup, and 8 oz. of sour cream (to give it that strogonoff "tang").  I also added about 1/2 to 3/4 of a cup of chicken stock in the beginning only because I was at work and didn't want to have it get done too quickly.  I drained the juice, added the soup and sour cream, and added the juice a little at a time to get the right consistency.  Served mixed with egg noodles..was super good!  Will definitely make again!

text:
I read the other reviews and I, too, changed it up a bit.  I used Knorr's Vegetable Soup mix, 'cause that's what I had and I added a little wine and a little chicken broth(about 1/4 cup of each) to the mix in the crock pot.  Then when I got home and the mixture in the crock pot was done, I sauteed up some fresh sliced mushrooms in a little olive oil and wine....I added cream of mushroom soup instead of cream of chicken to the crock pot mixture.....added only 4 oz of cream cheese and when the mushrooms were done I tossed those in and mixed it until it was all creamy, hot and mixed....then served it over hot, buttered noodles.  Very good!

text:
This recipe is golden!  I knew it would be great an hour or so while cooking in my slow cooker.  The aroma was fantastic! The only addition I made was adding sauteed onions mentioned in earlier reviews.  At the beginning I put some chicken stock in with the chicken, dry salad dressing and sauteed onions because I was concerned that the chicken would dry out.  I also added some fresh garlic at some midpoint during the cooking. At the end, about an hour before serving, I whisked 4 ounces of fat free cream cheese with a can of  Cream of Chicken Soup (the low fat version)with a splash of milk. Will make it again and again!!!!!!!!!!

This was really good.  My husband and 10 month old both enjoyed it, as did I.  I did make a few small changes. country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!  I made a few alterations as other people suggested.  I used 1/4 cup of white cooking wine, 1/2 cup of chicken broth, and low sodium cream of chicken soup with my 4 defrosted/cubed chicken breasts.  I let all of that cook for 3.5 hours on low.  I then added lite cream cheese, and about a 1/3 cup of lite sour cream, letting that cook on high for a half hour.  When it was complete, I put the mixture over wheat egg noodles and viola!  It was an excellent, no hassle meal!  Would highly recommend!!!!!!

I made it exactly as directed, always comes out great. However this time my chicken breast were frozen cause I had waited a little to late in the day to start. Just before  I top it over egg noodles I always drizzle a little olive oil & a pinch of Italian seasonings on noodles & toss. Yum!

text:
I've made this a dozen times over the past year or so, never twice exactly the same and all were great. The one currently in the slow cooker has five large chicken breasts (we love leftovers frozen in microwaveable containers with sufficient cooked rice to feed the two of us). I cubed the chicken while it was still somewhat frozen. I also use cream of mushroom soup rather than chicken and even thrrow in an extra can of mushrooms. I cook it on low for 7 hours to make up for the extra as well as some extra stirring that I can't resist. Wife's whole extended family seek invites when they know I am making it.

Display Name:
Allie Galante

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2103433.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this all the time for my family. To help tone down the saltiness of the original recipe, we add a few tablespoons of Ranch dressing (the actually dressing, not the packet). It adds good flavor without the saltiness. Also, for a little extra flavor and a little extra liquid, we add a can of cream of celery soup. To finish it up, we add a pound of egg noodles one hour before the dish is supposed to be done (when you add the cream cheese and soups), to give it that stroganoff feel. If you're running short on time, you can cook it on high for 2.5 hours and still add the noodles, cream cheese, and soup an hour before it's going to be done.

text:
AMAZING!  I made a few changes-- used Lipton onion soup mix instead of the Italian dressing mix.  Reduced the cream cheese to half and added about 3/4 cup reduced fat half & half.  I also just shredded the chicken after it cooked rather than cube it.  I served it over thick German spaetzle-style noodles. My husband & kids love this so much, they want it once a week for dinner.  It's a kid pleaser for sure!  By the way, I have also made this in a pot on the stove and it turns out just about the same as the slow cooker!

Very good! I did substitute the dry italian dressing packet for actual italian dressing because I didn't have the packet other than that made it just the way the recipe called for. Made almost exact to the recipe and this was amazing! (I like to try the recipes as is before modifying them)

city:

country:
None
text:
This is soooo good!  First, I like to try the recipe exactly as written, so I put in the chicken, seasoning, and butter and cooked as written.  Honestly, do not put the soup in in the beginning...the chicken will not have the flavors cooked into it as intended if you do and I feel the flavor will be more dull.  There was plenty of natural juices with the butter to cook the chicken without drying.  After 5 hours I put in the whole chunk of softened cream cheese with the soup and stirred.  Now at this point I made 1 adjustment only because I felt the mixture was thicker than I would like, so I added 1/3 cup chicken broth and let it cook for a half hour. It was amazing!  No leftovers as we ate ourselves sick!  Will definitely make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My only complaint with this recipe is the nightmarish amount of sodium, but other reviews have addressed that issue fairly well. I've made this probably half a dozen times and have found that how salty it tastes is largely dependent on what brand of salad dressing mix you use. If you find it too salty, try stirring in sugar and/or lemon juice a half teaspoon at a time until the flavors are more balanced. If you don't think of this recipe until a couple of hours before dinner, it also works on the stovetop as long as you watch it carefully and keep the heat fairly low.

text:
Wow, this really works in the slow cooker! I've been making this same thing for years, but by tossing cut up chicken with dressing mix to coat, brown it in tbsp. butter and tbsp. olive oil in skillet, meanwhile heat cream cheese and soup in microwave until cream cheese melts, stir to combine, and then add cooked chicken to sauce. So I had some doubts about it turning out as well with the slow cooker method, but it worked great! The chicken pieces did brown a little, and I used 2 tbsp. butter not margarine.

text:
I just made this at work for a potluck. I was able to find all the ingredients at a nearby store (T*****) :) I doubled the recipe, and cooked it on high for 3.5 hours (NO lifting of the lid). After reading the reviews I only used half the amount of cream cheese. I changed nothing else. It cooked perfectly, falling apart (but still intact) tender little bites of chicken. I did check with a thermometer and it was up to temperature - 165 degrees. It was gone in 1 hour. I will say, there was too much sauce for the chicken, no big deal, but I might use half the amount of soup next time. I think this would be good with Rotel too. It's important to use the .7 ounce packet of Italian dressing mix, not the other size. I even got a compliment and a request for the recipe!

text:
Complete success!!!! I made a few changes. I seasoned the diced chicken with the italian dressing mix powder, but then i added 1/3 cup of marsala cooking wine, 1 can of fat free cream of chicken, 1 can of fate free mushroom. Mixed it all together and let it cook on a high for 2.5 hrs. Once the chicken is no longer pink and the soup is mixed/heated well I diced up a black of low fat cream cheese and added it to the chicken mixture in the pot. Mixed it really well when the chunks of cheese melted easily. Let is cook on low for 30 more mins and it was done. A huge hit my 5 yr old son, his babysitter and her friend. Hubby liked it too. Definitely will make this again.

text:
An exceptional recipe to use as a base. I combined frozen chicken tenderloins, fresh sliced mushrooms, a 1/2 stick of butter, a can of cream of chicken, a can of cream of mushroom with roasted garlic, a packet of Italian seasoning, and a 1/4 cup of Marsala wine into the crock pot and set it on low for 5 hours. I then added 8 oz of cream cheese and allowed the flavors to blend for another hour before serving over hot cooked, whole wheat egg noodles. It was the perfect comfort food for a cold, blustery winter day.

text:
This is my go-to slow cooker recipe! I add mushrooms and a yellow onion, and really you could add any type of veggie that you and your family enjoy. I also like adding a jar of Philadelphia Italian Herbs & Cheese Cooking Creme, which adds a nice extra bit of creaminess and flavor. It is just delicious. You can serve it over any pasta or rice...you can eat it all on its own...you can sub chicken thighs (cheaper)...and you can even sub a variety of low-fat items to make it healthier. Turns out great every time!

text:
Loved this recipe! I took the advice of some previous raters, I used 1/4 cup white wine vinegar, sliced up onion and shallots, celery and carrots, placed all of it on the bottom, then i used chicken breast and sliced them up into chicken finger size and added the butter and Italian seasoning(I mixed them together as well) and poured it on top along with 2 of the knorrs chicken stock, along with pepper, minced onion, paprika and a dash of sea salt. when the chicken was done, I then shredded them into bite size pieces, added the cream cheese and 2 cans of condensed chicken soup, with parsely, a pinch of cajun seasoning, montreal chicken seasoning, and a bit more pepper and paprika, and added a bag of mixed veggies-peas, carrots, corn and beans. made some egg noodles-and OMG! The chicken was moist, gravy was delicious! I will make this again and again, but maybe make some mashed potatoes for the yummy gravy or add them to the crock pot! My boyfriend loved this dish! and it was even better the next day when I had it for lunch!
Review:

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for dinner yesterday for company and everyone had seconds!  I used cubed chicken and half a packet of Italian dressing mix as suggested by others with some melted Smart Balance.Also added a bit of red wine I was trying to get rid of as well as some carrots and chopped onions. House smelled amazing! Cooked on low for 3 1/2 hours then added a brick of low fat cream cheese, a can of cream of mushroom soup and a can of cream of chicken mixed with some milk. Also added some minced garlic, black pepper, parsley, and peas and kept it on low for about 30 minutes. Had to keep adding milk as the sauce was a bit thick. Served over whole wheat egg noodles. Will definitely be making this again!!!

text:
I had been really excited to make this but I did not care for it.  I made it exactly as the recipe read and 5 hours was way too long for the chicken.  I had to pick out the burnt rubbery pieces before adding the sauce.  The sauce was thick and pasty and tasted really bland.  If I were ever to make this again, I'd only cook the chicken for 3 1/2 hours.  I'd add some white wine and fresh mushrooms to give it more flavor.

text:
Another fantastic slow cooker recipe. I didn't make any alterations to it, but I do suggest softening the cream cheese in the microwave before mixing it with the soup. I didn't do it when I made it and I had some lumps in it. I had to take the chicken out and whisk it to smooth everything out. Even my son (8 years old) liked this one and he doesn't like anything with a sauce on it (unless it's spaghetti). In fact, he liked it so much he said "Mom, you should enter a cooking contest. This is great!" :) I definitely recommend this one for a twist on the standard beef stroganoff.

text:
Easy to make and tastes good.  I can't give it 5 stars because I altered the recipe. I didn't have a packet of salad dressing, so I had to make my own (Italian Dressing mix from this site). I took about 2 tbsp of the salad dressing mix and mixed it with a tbsp of olive oil and white wine vinegar.  I used a bag of frozen chicken tenders and it took about 5 hrs to cook (I did the last hour on high). I will make this again since it was pretty easy and still tasted good. I served with green beans and buttered bread.

text:
Amazingly good and easy! My wife raved about it for DAYS!!

My obligatory revisions:  I used 5 pounds of chicken thighs with the skin removed--this was from a 10-lb bag of chicken quarters, but I saved the drumsticks for another dish.

To this, I added two packages of dry Italian dressing mix (store brand), 1/4 cup butter (yes, butter) and let it cook for about six hours on low.  I then added two cans of cream of chicken soup and only one brick of cream cheese, and let it cook on high for about another hour.

The chicken bones from the thighs just add a little more body to the sauce.

Served over hot rice with a slice of homemade sourdough bread on the side.

To quote my DW: To. Die. For. :-)

text:
I am a dedicated & unapologetic food snob.  I normally eschew anything w an ingredient that reads "cream of _______." But I was trying to come up w something my 10yo niece could learn to cook & this seemed to fit the bill nicely.  I fully expected it to be edible but unremarkable.  I was wrong! It was really very tasty.  We doubled the amount of chicken & it came out just fine.  And to keep it really kid easy I had her put whole frozen chicken breasts into the slowcooker & just ran it on low for about 6h.  Didn't even bother to cube the chicken - everyone was just served a breast w the sauce over some egg noodles.  Not a bit was left! To jazz it up a bit I might throw in 1/2 C white wine in the future.

country:
None
text:
This is absolutely amazing!!!! So flavorful and easy. My only suggestion: Make extra, your family will devour this!!!! Those that are complaining about it being too salty or slimy...simply cut back on the seasoning and adjust the cooking time. Some Crock Pots are just different. You can also cut the cream cheese in half and perhaps just use a little cream instead to scale back the rich flavor.

Part 2: Since making this the first time, I have recently began watching my calories. My suggestion for all you weigh watchers: Eliminate the margarine and use reduced fat cream of chicken. I'd keep the creamed cheese full fat, as this can really molest the flavor. Also, the calorie count does not include the pasta. I simply added my pasta (about three or four cups) and then spread the recipe out over 8 servings versus 4. Only 259 calories a serving including the pasta! I hope this helps.

I was real excited to try this recipe!! I made it today going on instinct since Ia m not eating any typ eof meat during lent. I did not have the Italian dressing mix on hand so I used a package of green onion mix instead and also added in a splash of white wine along with the butter. After about 30 minutes I went ahead and added in some Italian Season Seasoning(maybe about a teaspoon). I also used chicken thighs because that is what I had in the freezer. Everything else I followed the recipe. My husband and 16 year old son who are both not prone to tasting new foods wolfed it down and barely left enough for the girls!!! It was so simple to make! I think it would look great with some steamed asparagus! I look forward to trying it myself after Easter!

country:
None
text:
This recipe was pretty tasty.  My boyfriend really liked it, but I wasn't as big of a fan.  I told him I would only make it again upon request because it was definitely not my favorite.  Here are some reasons why:

--  Texture: I'm not a huge fan of slow-cooked chicken.  I was willing to give it a shot for the sake of the recipe, but I was eating it I just kept thinking about how it would be so more delicious if I made this in the oven.  The chicken was dry in chunks.  I recommend shredding it if you use the slow cooker.

-- Description/Ingredients: The word stroganoff seems to be a bit misleading.  I guess I could have decided that based on the ingredients, but this definitely has more of a taste of a chicken casserole than any sort of stroganoff.  Tasty, yes.  Stroganoff? no.  Then again, maybe I just don't know what Stroganoff means (very possible).

--  Flavor: While a tasty meal, yes, it is a lot of the same flavor without adding veggies or other good seasonings/spices.  I added a ton of frozen mixed veggies (peas, carrots, etc.).  This is where I started really liking this meal.  :)

--  Consistency of Sauce:  I had to water it down a lot as many of the reviews mentioned.  It tasted very... umm... cream cheesy in texture and kinda flavor too.

Pretty good meal, but because of all the reasons listed above, I give it 3 stars.  Worth trying, but consider your preferences and trust your recipe-tweaking gut instinct.  :)

There seems to be lots of mixed reviews on this, but, my husband LOVED it! I enjoyed it, too. It was super easy to make. First, I sprayed my crockpot before adding the breasts. WAY TOO SALTY!  I made this tonight and the only thing I did differently was put a little cooking sherry in with the chicken so it would not burn to the crock pot. text:
So, so good!!  I made it once as is, and it tasted good.  But tonight I had some extra chopped onion & zucchini from another dish I was making (about a 1/2 c each) and threw that in there.  At the end after turning the slow cooker off, I added a 6-oz box of Uncle Ben's quick-cooking long grain & wild rice (w/o seasoning) and let it sit for about 10 minutes (also reduced cream cheese to 3/4)...it made the dish outstanding!  Of course, it turned it into a casserole-like consistency, but I was going to be serving it with rice anyway, so thought I might as well add it in there ahead of time.

Perfect for crazy days.  I made this to have dinner ready for my family tonight beacause I have a dinner meeting, but I tasted it and it's good.  I used cut-up chicken tenders, 1 lb., and had enough sauce to cover twice that amount of chicken.  Used butter instead of margarine (and only 1 Tbs) , Zesty Italian dressing mix, 1/3 less fat cream cheese and Cream of Mushroom and Roasted Garlic soup.  Added a splash of white wine when adding the soup and cream cheese.  Served over brown rice with steamed broccoli on the side.  This is a great recipe to have in your back pocket for days like today.  Yum!  Wish I were eating at home tonight!

text:
I tried this last night, and after reading a ton of the reviews, both good and bad, I decided to tweak it just a bit.  I added about 1/2 cup of diced onion to the chicken/butter/seasoning mix.  And after about two hours of cooking, I added 1/2 cup of white wine.  I only cooked the chicken for about four hours on low, and then I added 98% fat free cream of mushroom soup and only 1/2 of the cream cheese (and I used 1/3 fat cream cheese).  The chicken was moist and the sauce wasn't too thick at all.  If I'd added all of the cream cheese, I think it would have been too thick and overpowering.  My family enjoyed it.  I'm not sure how often I'll make it, but it was good and super-easy.

text:
This recipe wasn't one of my favorites. First of all, i am not a huge fan of chicken breasts in the slow cooker. They shred down to a canned chicken quality taste. Dark meat slow cooks much nicer. And I only use the best quality chicken. Gotta sty away from hormones, antibiotics and God knows what else. Definitely use mushrooms. They give it a little kick. And use thighs instead of breasts.

text:
Very good, very easy recipe and went very very well with egg noodles.  I replaced the cream of chicken soup with cream of mushroom and used chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts.  The only thing I would change next time will be to cut back on the cream cheese.  We found that, with an entire block of cream cheese, you could distinctly taste cream cheese.  While it didn't overwhelm the other flavours, it didn't nicely balance with the chicken and mushroom flavours.  Will definitely make again.

What a simple and wonderful crockpot meal to keep on hand!  I followed this recipe's ingredients exactly...The only change I made was to increase the sauce amount a bit (as I was serving 6 people) by using 1 1/2 pkg. cream cheese and 1 1/2 cans of cream of chicken soup.  The other amounts I left the same and it turned out wonderfully.  After you cook the chicken in the seasoning and butter, it literally shreds apart in the slow cooker; so moist and tender!  I served over egg noodles.  I made this for my family plus my mother and sister when they came to visit and they had second helpings!  Will definitely be making this simple yet flavorful dish again! Okay -- It was a struggle but I followed the directions exactly. By not adding the soup (or any water/wine) at the beginning, the chicken cooked in a way that almost browned or seared. I did however, let the butter melt completely and ensured it completely covered the base before adding the chicken. I also added the entire packet of dry Italian dressing (some suggested only using half).   This was a success for my family - I would make this again. I might consider adding some additional spices or using a more robust mix (I used mild). I considered it slightly bland - although my husband loved it and stroganoff in general is mild.

This is great, very tasty and good enough for company. I did follow the advice of some other reviewers, however, and it really made this a five star dish. I also used fat free cream cheese, and it was still rich and delicious. I'll definitely be making this again.

text:
I thought this was great and easy. I will try reduced or fat free ingredients next time to reduce fat. *** Also, cooking in butter only will not dry it out, I came home after cooking on low for 4 1/2 hours and it was not dried up or burnt, actually gave it a good "roasted" flavor I don't think would have been accomplished by adding stuff before cooking. ***SUPER DELICIOUS UPDATE 1/7/11: I wanted to jazz this up a bit, so I started my chicken in the crock, then after maybe 2 hours added a can of drained, diced italian tomatoes in olive oil. After another 3 or 4 hours I added cream of mushroom soup instead of chicken, and chive and onion cream cheese instead of plain. Also added just a splash of white wine swirled around in the mushroom soup can. Cooked on high for a good 30 minutes, stirred and ate over egg noodles. Man was this really good! Original recipe is great I just wanted to spice things up a bit and it worked out wonderfully. Hubby even left me a note (works late, eats dinner after I am in bed) on how wonderful dinner was and that he really enjoyed it! He is the (amazing) cook in the family, so leaving a note on how great dinner was really says a lot about how great the meal turned out. If he is impressed it is definately a success!

Fabulous! I only made a few small changes, but after making this recipe a few times it is very forgiving. I did not add the butter/margarine and did add a can-ful of water bc otherwise the soup was to thick and browned in the crockpot.  I put the chicken, soup, water and italian mix in the crock pot to start. Then 30-45 before serving I added the cream cheese.   There was no need to cut the chicken as it falls apart after being cooked.

text:
I did not cube the chicken---I just placed frozen chcken breasts into the slow cooker---they stayed together and each person was able to place their chicken breast, with sauce, over the pasta. Added fresh, sliced portabella mushrooms. Used low fat cream cheese. Added low fat sour cream (about 3/4 cup). Kept the temperature at low, but changed to the "keep warm" temperature to avoid the sauce from browning up on the sides of the cooker. Was fantastically delicious and enjoyed by the pickiest of eaters.

text:
This was the most delicious dinner. I did follow some advice from other reviewers: Skipped the margarine, I did not have italian dressing mix, so I used light zesty italian dressing, 1 can Healthy Request Crm of Chicken soup and 1 can Healthy Request Crm of Mushrom soup thinned with about 3/4 c. milk. I let it cook for about five hours until it was moist and tender, falling apart. Shredded the chicken and then I added 4 oz. 1/3 less-fat cream cheese and about 1/2 c. of sour cream. I let it cook in the crockpot for another 45 minutes to let the flavors blend. Served it over whole wheat egg noodles and it was amazing!.

text:
I doubled the recipe and used two entire seasoning packets, two cans cream of mushroom soup and one can cream of chicken soup (should have used one less can of soup, though).  Since my last crock pot recipe came out extremely dry, I was afraid to start the chicken off with so little liquid, so I put two cans of the soup and ¾ c. vermouth (no white wine on hand) in at the beginning.  I’ll use less liquid next time since I ended up having to thicken the final product.  30 minutes before this was done, I added some sautéed mushrooms, garlic, and onion, and did some additional seasoning with oregano, basil, garlic powder, rosemary, paprika, and pepper.  Served over egg noodles—yum!

text:
My husband LOVED this, but I did make some changes to the basic recipe.  Since I worry about sodium for us both, I used only half the Italian dressing mix, adding more oregano, basil, fresh rosemary, and fresh garlic.  I didn't use the whole 8 oz. brick of cream cheese, probably more like 2/3 of it, and I stirred in some sauteed sliced onion and baby portabellos with the cream cheese and soup.  I worried it would be too thick after reading reviews, so I stirred in about 1/4 cup of vermouth; if I had had white wine, I would have used that.  I served it over brown rice, and my husband raved about it.  Actually, I had bought sour cream to add as well, but I forgot it!

text:
This is the best recipe I've ever gotten from the internet.  I didn't have Italian dressing mix, so I used Lori's suggestion for "Italian Herb Salad Dressing mix Clone" at www.recipezaar.com and used 1 tsp. oregano, basil, paprika and freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 tsp. onion powder, 1 TBS garlic powder, and two tablespoons of granulated sugar.  I also added 2 cups of chicken stock when I added the cream of chicken soup because so many people have said the sauce was too thick.  I also added a little garlic salt to taste at the end.  I have to say, it didn't LOOK real appetizing, but, smelling it all day long sure made everyone eager to taste it.  My WHOLE family LOVED it.  My husband said, "This is definitely a 'do it again' recipe" and he's picky about textures.  My son made a face at the way it looked,but, gobbled it up and asked for seconds and thirds!  I will definitely make this again and again, and share the recipe with my friends!

text:
I made this the other night and it was fabulous!  I used four chicken breasts, cubed.  I cooked them with a whole packet of Good Season's Italian dressing mix in the crockpot on low for about 4 hours.  I then added 4oz of cream cheese, two big scoops of sour cream and a can of cr. of mushroom soup.  I let it cook on high for about 45 min and it was great.  The chicken was super moist and the sauce was thick enough to stick to egg noodles well.  The leftover were even better the next day!  I felt the full packet of seasoning was the right amount and the mixture of cream cheese and sour cream made the sauce just right.

text:
I just got done making this for dinner, and had to review it - it is wonderful!  I am not a mushroom fan, and was excited to see a stroganoff recipe without them.  Every last bit was eaten up, even by my picky son. I think I could have doubled the recipe and it still would have all gone! I used the Zesty Good Seasons dressing. I was concerned about the chicken burning, so I did add about 1/3 cup white wine at the beginning, and am glad I did, both to keep the chicken moist, and add more flavor. I also cut back the cream cheese to 4 oz and stirred in about 1/2 cup of sour cream. I served it with wide egg noodles. I am glad I had peas, broccoli and carrots on the side, because the presentation would have been pretty bland without them. I ended up stirring the peas into my own serving, which complemented the taste so well that I may add them to the crock pot with the cream cheese and soup next time.  Thanks for the great recipe; we will be eating this again soon!

text:
This was really quite good. The Italian dressing adds a LOT. I TRIPLED the recipe using the meat from chickens I had cooked (boiled) previously rather than the chicken breasts. Also, I NEVER use condensed soups in recipes so what I did instead was toss 3 celery ribs (chopped) and 3 T. of butter into the crockpot along with 3 chicken bouillon cubes, "some" dried parsley (probably about 3 T.) and 3/4 cup of water at the onset. When I added the cream cheese (2 12 oz "blocks") I also added 1/2 lb. container of (fresh) sliced mushrooms, approx. 2 T. Cornstarch and 1 cup of milk (Half&Half would work well, too). Upon serving (over 2 pkgs. BROAD PD egg noodles, cooked separately), I made salt, black and cayenne pepper, paprika and sour cream available for "takers". We are 6 pretty "averaged size" adults -- but when dinner was over and I set the leftovers down for my dogs, both of them looked up at me with kind of an "is that all that's left?" expression on their faces. [I gave this a 4 on account of the changes I made, but given my changes, I'd rate it a 10+ and a definite keeper.]

I absolutism LOVE this recipe. I give it 5 stars even though I had to modify it. I took some pointers from other reviewers. I add white wine to the pot to cook w/ the chicken all day. . . and I use real butter instead of margarine. 

The house smells soooooo good all day and I get complements from all my daycare kids parents when they come to pick up their kids. 

Once I know the chicken is cooked through I can't help but sneak bites - I have learned to make more chicken than needed because of this. It's so good just like that.  I've given away this recipe numerous times.

YUM YUM YUM!!  This recipe is AWESOME!  The chicken is very tender & juicy and the sauce is amazing!  It goes well over rice or pasta.  I made only two changes:  I added about 1/3 - 1/2 cup of red wine and about 1 lb sliced fresh mushrooms to the crockpot in the beginning.
Also - cook times will vary depending on the size and brand of your crockpot . . .mine cooks 4 servings in only 3 hours (on low!).  So just watch out and keep an eye on it so you don't overcook the chicken.  :)

text:
This was "OK". Made this tonight for my bf and I. While I liked it (he, not so much), I didn't care for it enough to add to my regular menu rotation. I guess I just don't care for slow cooked chicken... The texture is kinda wierd. As for preparation, I pretty much followed the recipe to a T except for adding about 1/4 c. of chicken broth in the first step (I had some left-over from another recipe that I wanted to use up). One thing to note, however, is that it took much longer than 30 minutes (on low setting) for my cream cheese to completely melt (even though I softened it in the microwave beforehand). This was not a problem since I needed to boil pasta and warm my veggie side. One suggestion for those who want to make this.... Mix your cream cheese and soup together before adding to the crock pot (it's easier than stirring with the chicken). Served over wide egg noodles with a side of canned peas and dinner rolls. Thanks for sharing!

text:
This was fantastic!! I used 4 frozen chicken breasts instead of diced chicken.  I mxed together 2 Tbsps of melted butter, a tsp of dried minced garlic, 2 Tbsps of dried minced onion and 1/2 pkg of salad dressing mix to 1/2 cup Chardonay and poured that into the crock pot with the chicken breasts. For the sauce, I used a 3 oz pkg of low fat cream cheese, 1/2 cup low fat sour cream and the can of soup.  I also added a cup or so of fresh mushrooms. I served the chicken breasts, topped with the mushrooms and sauce, with potatoes and a vegetable.  Unbelievably easy and so good!!

I tried this recipe (following it exactly as stated) because of all the high reviews but was very disappointed!  The only reason I even give it two stars is because the chicken by itself, with the italian seasoning and margarine, turned out very good and would be great by itself or on buttery noodles. text:
I used frozen chicken breasts, sprinkled with 1/2 pkg Tastefully Simple's "Garlic Garlic," covered with 1 can undiluted Golden Mushroom soup and cooked on Low for 4 hours. Added one 8-oz brick of cream cheese cut into 6 cubes for 30 mins to soften, then added 1 can undiluted Cream of Chicken soup, let cook while the noodles boiled, then spooned over. My 7 and 9-yr olds gave this TEN STARS and this recipe feeds our family of 4 twice.   Served over wide egg noodles with petite green peas on the side, and cheesey garlic toast. A little starchy but delicious and easy! Thanks for the post, this one's a keeper.

text:
YUMMMMM - SOOOOO GOOD! The most creamy, comforting chicken dish I think I've made to date. I modified the recipe only slightly: Prior to cooking the chicken, I sprinkled dried tarragon & herbs de provence over top the breasts, along with some garlic powder, fresh black pepper & minced onion. Rather than cutting the breasts into cubes, I shredded them prior to adding the cream of chicken soup - and I took the advice of some others & used only a half a block of cream cheese (reduced fat) and 2 heaping big spoonfuls of reduced fat sour cream. It was SO delicious!! I served it over mini penne pasta with a salad. Thanks so much - this will definitely become a fall/winter staple in my house!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This dish was awesome! However, I did adjust the recipe in several ways with suggestions from other people. This was my creation: Start with 2-1/2 cups of frozen veggie mix (broccoli, green beans, onions, and mushrooms), 3 breasts of chicken (cubed), 1/2 a packet of Italian seasoning, 1/4 cup of water, and 3 tbsp of margarine all in a crock pot on low for 3-4 hours. Then add 1/2 cup of light sour cream, 4 tbsp of light cream cheese, and 1 can of both low sodium/low fat cream of chicken and cream of mushroom soup. Stir it all up and let cook for another hour. (Add a little bit of water if too thick.) Because I had broccoli in there, it actually came out with a little but of a broccoli cheese flavor, but my boyfriend and I loved it! Much recommended recipe.

The whole family loves this recipe, and so do the freinds I have passed it onto. Reader modifications make it even better. I also use the 1/3 less fat cream cheese, and the low sodiumd/low cream of chicken soup. Cream of mushroom soup is also a tasy alternative. SOme leftover broccoli florets, pea, or mushrooms are also options for addition to this tasty meal.  For those who have tried it and thought it too thick,crcokpots are like micrwaves-they are not all the same-you may need to adjust the amount of liquid you add. I very often skip the crockpot all together! Making this in a deep skillet is super quick and just as tasty!

text:
I made this when I was looking for something new and different. It is excellent. My kids are not crazy about a traditional stroganoff, so I thought this might work better since there is no sour cream and no beef. First, it smells wonderful, I added a second envelope of dressing mix, however, it also made it a little salty. I think this could be fixed by adding the second envelope to the soup instead of the chicken since only the chicken was salty not the sauce. I also added two cans of soup thinned with 1/2 c.milk since we like sauce, and I served it over penne. I'm going to make this again today since it has been a couple of weeks since we tried it the first time. I see this as a regular in our rotation.

text:
My family really enjoyed this meal. I did vary the recipe a bit. I took the advise of others and cooked the chicken in the soup. ( I used 2 cans of soup; 1 cream of chicken and 1 cream of mushroom. We like extra sauce) I used only 1/2 a pack of the Italian dressing mix. The last 45 min. I added only 4 oz of soft cream cheese, 4 oz. of fat free sour cream and fresh sliced mushrooms. I smelled wonderful while it was cooking and tasted just as good. Served it with noodles, peas and tossed salad. No leftovers. Thanks Judi, this one is a keeper.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very salty. After reading VVGROVER's comments, I altered the recipe because we don't like the taste of much salt. I used 1/3 of an 8-oz brick of cream cheese (to cut the fat content), and an entire .65 oz. packet of Good Seasons Zesty Italian dressing mix. While this was an easy recipe and made the house smell wonderful, I won't make it again. Way too salty, even after adding soy milk and wide yolkless noodles to the pot at the end. Husband said it's bland, and even if I'd added peas or some other veggies to it (I added just sliced fresh mushrooms toward the end), the sauce would still be too bland. And did I mention salty?!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My friend sent me this recipe years ago after having it at her house, and I've been making it ever since!! It's delicious, satisfying, easy, and great for leftovers!  My sisters and mother have also stolen the recipe after having it at my house. I follow the directions to a T, except instead of cubing the chicken beforehand, I just throw the chicken breasts in halved, and they shred very easily once everything is cooked. I find it to be much quicker, and more sanitary, since I prefer to keep my handling of raw meat to a minimum. Sometimes I halve the amount of chicken, if it's just me at home, but I've also doubled the entire recipe when feeding more than 4.

This was a simple and tasty recipe.  I did notice that, after cooking 4 hours on low, there was very little moisture in the crock pot so I added about 1 cup of water to keep the chicken chunks from drying out. text:
Tasty and very easy. I've made it several times and serve it over egg noodles. 

Cooking for 5 to 6 hours is too long for my cooker for such small piece of chicken (~4 is enough), but I don't fault the recipe for that since slow cookers are inconsistent. Aside from that and adding some salt/pepper to taste toward the end, I follow the recipe as written.

(Incidentally, it's always good to see a slow cooker recipe that understands there's no need to drown things in liquid)
