text:
My version turned out awful and inedible.  It doesn't taste at all like real stroganoff.  It is extremely salty and the Italian dressing leaves a weird aftertaste.  In addition, by cubing the chicken before cooking and putting it in with no liquid, after just a few hours (I gave it 3.5 hours) the chicken is tough and unpleasant.  I do take some responsibility for changing the recipe--I like a lot of sauce, so I doubled the sauce ingredients (twice the cream cheese, twice the soup, a packet and a half of the seasoning) and added 3/4 of a cup of chicken broth to thin it a bit.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  Wanted to make a stroganoff but beef is so expensive and not as good for you as chicken, so I checked this wonderful web site and found this recipe.  I made my own dry Italian dressing (from this site) and cooked as written - not adding the soup until later.  I did add half of a large onion (diced) at the beginning with the chicken and dressing.  After 5 hours I added "roasted garlic cream of mushroom" soup and a package of fresh mushrooms.  Let that cook another 2 hours and added the brick of cream cheese.  Let it sit a bit before stirring it into the sauce, it incorporates much easier.  I boil my egg noodles and add them at the end and let it all marry together for awhile - then eat.  YUM!  I am very sure you can throw everything in at the beginning at let it go all day without any problems.  Thanks for this keeper!

text:
The chicken cooked fine from raw with just margarine & 1pack of seasoning. I didn't peek so maybe that helped. This is a fantastic recipe, I doubled everything except the seasoning & chicken (only had 4breasts on hand) and it probably would have been enough but both the daughters came home along with a boyfriend so our usual 3ppl became 6. After I had half a cup with cut tortillas left over from enchilada casserole, and 2bowls for the oldest & bf (they thought it was "the best soup mum!"),  I stretched the rest with noodles a bit of sour cream (3Tbsp tops) and a splash of milk. The remaining daughter, husband & brother insist it goes on next months menu so they must have liked it.
It's a good thing the family is mostly skinny ppl that must eat minimum of 2500cal/day to maintain weight...

country:
None
text:
Thank you for the great and easy recipe!  I had a somewhat interesting experience with it...my wife and I both work long hours and so I knew the 5 hour cook time was going to be an issue...so I experimented.  I put the chicken breasts in the slow cooker frozen, added the butter and Italian dressing mix, and put the cooker on low.  I returned home 9 hours later to find my chicken breasts cooked "well done" but not burnt, but they were surrounded by burnt crust.  After sampling a bite to test palatability, I decided to roll with it and transferred them to a saucepan where I shredded them and added the cream cheese and cream of chicken soup.  I ended up with a nice shredded chicken dip :).  Still improvising, I added the juice of a lemon (I prefer a lot of "tang" in this dish), a can of cream of mushroom and 2 soup cans of water.  This gave it the consistency I enjoy...will do it again when I can return in the 5 hour time frame and I think I will add the cream of mushroom, lemon juice and maybe even some sliced mushrooms.  Thanks again!

text:
I made this recipe for my mother in law (first time cooking for her) and she absolutely loved this meal!  I didn't follow the recipe exactly and it turned out better than I anticipated.  I used 1 can of low fat cream of chicken soup and 1 can of low fat cream of mushroom soup. Chopped up half of an onion and cooked with the chicken breast in the slow cooker for about 6 hours on low.  I then shredded the chicken and added half a package of low fat cream cheese, 2 spoonful's of sour cream and half the .7 oz bag of dry Italian dressing seasoning. Cooked for another hour or so on low until we were ready to eat!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1617949.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found this reciepe to be delicious and my family loved it as well!  However, I did make a few changes because we had a few guests stop by the house (7 people total)so I increased the amount of chicken to 10 chicken breasts cubed,1 stick of butter, 3 packs of the dry Italian seasoning, 1 tbsp of Garlic powder,1 tbsp of onion powder. I tossed the ingredients around in the slower cooker and let it cook on high for 3 hours 15 mins. I then used 1 8oz container of onion and chive cream cheese, and 8 oz of can mushrooms and then mixed into the crockpot and let it cook for an additional 30 mins on high (while it was cooking I did stir the mixture to make sure the cream cheese was throughly incorporated throughout) I boiled 1 bag of large egg noodle which I tossed with 1/4 stick of butter,a pinch of salt and pepper,three cheese parmisian,and dry parsley and placed stroganoff mixture over the top. It was fast, and delicious and I will definitely be cooking it again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
To be honest, I shouldn't really be reviewing this recipe because I didn't use a slow cooker, and that's a pretty serious deviation from the recipe.  I also used pre-cooked chicken breasts from a whole chicken I made earlier this week.  I'm pretty much reviewing on the flavor profile only, which was absolutely amazing! I melted the butter in a big skillet, added the Italian seasoning mix and cubed, cooked chicken, and stirred constantly for a few minutes.  Then I added the last couple of ingredients and stirred until the cheese melted and incorporated.  My only problem was that, since I didn't use a slow cooker, I didn't have enough liquid (I'm guessing the slow cooker would have rendered some off from the chicken).  So I just thinned it out with some pasta water from the egg noodles I served the sauce over.  Creamy, thick, and deliciously seasoned--awesome!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/870929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was AMAZING! Don't eat too much, calorie count is crazy. I threw in a bunch of fresh mushrooms to extend it for a family of 6 with 3 very active teenagers whom need a lot of calories.. I don't know how the italian seasoning did it, but the chicken was NOT dry! it was the juiciest chicken ever made in a crock pot. The mushrooms were perfect, half cooked down. Couldn't stop eating them as I waited for everyone. Had to add more.

 You don't have to cook for 7 hours. I cooked for 2.5, stirred the chicken a couple times during cooking. then added the soup and brick, let go about half an hour and added the mushrooms when i saw the portions, another can of soup and half a brick more of cheese. cooked until all melted. It was ready after just 3.5 hours, turned crock put off ( so it wouldn't burn.) until dinnertime, heated through again

We all loved it!! served with crusted bread and green beans.

text:
Great starter recipe with lots of room for alteration. Based on other reviewers' suggestions, I halved the the cream cheese and added about 1/4 cup of white wine. I also put the soup (98% fat free) in at the beginning of the cooking time, and only added the cream cheese at the very end. Lastly, I used boneless skinless chicken thighs instead of breast meat. Very yummy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/360946.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really delicious and easy. I tried to lower the huge sodium count (the reason for only 4 stars) by using "Healthy Choice" Cream of Chicken soup, as well as adding the lowest sodium dry salad dressing available. I also used lower fat cream cheese (Neufchatel cheese, which is exactly like cream cheese and is available at any grocery store). Because it's stroganoff, I felt compelled to add about 2/3 cup of sauteed fresh mushrooms. I sauteed the mushrooms for about 7 or 8 minutes in a little butter, then added them at the same time as the soup and cream cheese. I stirred about a tablespoon of the mushroom liquid into the stroganoff. The flavor was surprisingly rich and savory. I served the dish over wide egg noodles with steamed peas on the side; it was a big hit with the family. Will definitely make again.

Excellent recipe. As another reviewer said, no need to turn it on high after adding the cream cheese. Just keep it on low for an hour rather than a half hour. text:
Oh my, this is delicious! My only regret is not doubling the recipe! (I like to cook enough to last a couple of days, and my husband and I will go through this in just one!) Thanks to the reviewers who offered reassurance that the chicken will be okay with just that tiny amount of butter to keep it moistened; although I did cook it for only 4 hours before adding the wet ingredients, as my crock-pot is pretty big, and stuff seems to cook more quickly in it than most recipes indicate it will. I also added a 4oz can of sliced mushrooms, half an onion, and either a quarter cup or half a cup of milk, I forget which. This will definitely be one of my "go-to" staple recipes in the future!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe as written, as I typically do the first time I make a recipe, then I tweak from there.  I was skeptical, but I added the soup/cream cheese later in the cooking time as suggested.  That part was fine - although I'm not really sure what benefit you get from adding it later as the chicken sort of poaches in the butter and doesn't get brown or anything (at least it didn't for me).  The part that made me rate this recipe as "ok" was the Italian dressing mix. The mix packet made the dish just too salty for our tastes.  Like some other reviewers have said, next time I will either add 1/2 a packet, use regular Italian dressing, or just add my own herbs and spices.  I served it over brown rice (totally unseasoned) and with broccoli (also totally unseasoned, on purpose to dilute some of the salty taste when we mixed the chicken with the rice and broccoli) and that seemed to work pretty well.  My family didn't complain of it being salty all mixed together, but after dinner my husband did say "I'm so thirsty!" so even though he didn't equate that with the saltiness of the dish, I did!

I was unable to find a packet of of Italian salad-dressing mix without MSG, so I improvised with the spices from this recipe: Allrecipes' Italian Dressing Mix. I left out some of the salt because there were a lot of reviews saying how salty this was.

Like many other reviewers, I put in the soup at the beginning, and even that was not sufficient, it was dry when I came home at six hours. However, I put in the cream cheese and some chicken broth and was able to save it. Delicious!

text:
I FINALLY got to make this.  IT. IS.  WONDERFUL!  Instead of the cream of chicken soup..I found a recipe for home made cream of chicken soup.  I also added a little celery salt in the end. Next time I think I will add my own herbs instead of the Italian salad dressing mix.  And I could see adding chopped artichokes to this.  YUM
Just made this again. This time I used a can of cream of chicken soup but I didn't have the Dry italian dressing mix. So I made my own from a recipe on here called "Italian Dressing Mix" by Debby. I cut up some left over cooked turkey and placed it in a pot with the dressing mix with a cup of low sodium chicken broth. I did not add the salt and used garlic powder instead of garlic salt...did use celery salt tho and it was perfect.  I let that slowly warm and sit for a few hours on the stove so the ingredients would blend together...then I added the soup and cream cheese and it is sitting on warm until the hub gets home. I will serve it over rice.  I've already had several tastes and it's so good. I think I will sub a bit of nutmeg for the sugar in the Italian dressing for this next time. Also think I will add sour cream next time!!  Oh...and I make this on the stove...comes out perfect as well!

If you don't like reviews that change up the recipe, don't read this one! I didn't end up doing slow cooker because of how my day was going, so I cooked the chicken seprately with montreal chicken seasoning and olive oil and I put the sauce ingredients in a big pot and stirred until bubbly. text:
Delicious dinner!  This has been in my recipe box for a year and eight months.  Not sure why I waited so long to make this.  I used the ingredients listed; only making 'Italian Dressing Mix' from AR for the dressing listed and a fat-free soup.  Mine cooked for 9 hours on low in my crock-pot, but the chicken still had a nice firm texture to it.  I have an older crock-pot that doesn't heat as hot as the new ones.  The leftovers of this were every bit as good as the first time around.  We had this over egg noodles along with a salad and bread.  I will most definitely be using this recipe again.  Thanks JUDI ANN for sharing.

text:
This dish was absolutely fantastic! The dressing mix gives it such flavor. I don't even like salad dressings but in this recipe, it's a must! 

I changed it a little. I added fresh mushrooms and added a little half n'half to thin it out a little. It was still super creamy and thick but it needed a little help with the half n'half. I also did not use a crock pot but a pan. I put the butter, soup, and cream cheese into a pan to let melt, then added raw chicken and covered for about an hour. I highly recommend this recipe for comfort food lovers.

So easy and a great slow cooker recipe!  Resist the urge to add liquid in the beginning - it really does work as is.  Left this recipe for my husband to do while I was out, but he accidentally added a packet of ranch dressing instead of Italian dressing...whoops!  I added the Italian dressing packet as well when I got home and it turned out great.  I also added a package of frozen peas and some chopped carrots, and served it over egg noodles.  Next time I'll have to try it sans ranch to see the difference.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, YUM!!!  I just made this (eating it now!) and I had to do my review.  I was tired and didn't feel like fussing over dinner.  Luckily I came across this recipe and had everything on hand.  It was so easy to throw together.  I always read as many reviews as I can before trying, so here's what I got from reading:  I didn't cube the chicken, I just threw 4 frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot.  Then I went ahead and put in the soup.  Then threw in a few heaping spoons of margarine (I hate measuring it so I eyeball it).  Then I sprinkled half the packet of seasoning all over it.  Crockpot on low, stirring only once or twice and 5 hours later, perfect!  I shredded the chicken while egg noodles boiled.  Then I plopped in the cream cheese whole, let it sit a little before stirring and it melted right in.  I will say it is missing *something* small, but it's not the seasoning.  The seasoning is perfect.  I think next time I'd like to add a little sour cream for some of that extra pop of flavor.  But still 5 stars b/c it's perfect as is and everyone loved it!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-07-28T14:21:53.29
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
7299446
Display Name:
Renee Leith
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
79
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only had a whole chicken on hand. I cut the chicken into piece's, took all the skin off and cut away all the fat.  I added 1 can of healthy request cream of chicken soup at the start, along with 1/2 cup wine (chardonney), 1/2 cup of chicken broth, 1 cup of diced sweet onion, 1 cup of sliced mushrooms, and a package of ranch dressing (all I had on hand.) Started on high for 1 and 1/2 hours, (due to time restriction) then turned to low for 5 hours. (I've seen other cut up whole chicken crock pot recipes that call for 8 to 9 hours on low if you need.) After the first 5 hours of cooking, I took out of the crock, a cup of the hot cooked sauce, and mixed in 4 oz. of cream cheese. I let this cool and added 2 heaping tablespoons of flour to the sauce and cream cheese, then added it back into the crock for another hour and a half. I served it over low carb Dreamfield Penne with a shaving of asiago cheese. Delish!

For those who are complaining of too much salt: make your own italian dressing dry mix by searching for a recipe on this site. Then alter the salt content to your liking. Then use reduced salt cream of chicken soup mix. Most of us have the ingredients for the italian style dressing mix on hand in our seasoning cupboard. Which can help save a little $ as well.

I love this recipe as does my family! I've made it several times now and just wanted to share my suggestions, I also double this recipe, 4 hungry men!. Using all the ingrediants , I also add, 
tsp. smoked paprika, 1/2 tsp. garlic powder, 1/2 tsp. onion powder to the chicken. When adding your soups, I include 1 can cream mushroom soup, a 1/4 cup sherry. Let it simmer, serve over egg noodles, and top it with fresh shaved parmesan cheese.  Enjoy!

This is a keeper.  I did change it a bit. I omitted the margarine, I didn't have Italian style salad dressing mix so I used  1 1/2 teaspoons garlic powder
 1 tablespoon onion powder
 2 tablespoons oregano, ground or 2 tablespoons oregano leaves
1 tablespoon dried parsley
 1 tablespoon granulated sugar
 2 tablespoons salt or 2 tablespoons salt substitute
 1 teaspoon black pepper
 1 teaspoon ground basil or 1 teaspoon basil leaves
 1/4 teaspoon ground thyme or 1/4 teaspoon thyme leaves
and a teaspoon of celery salt

and I used creme of mushroom soup instead of crm of chix soup.  I put it over brown rice.  Yummy!!

This is amazing and so easy to make!! I made a few changes as per the reviews: Added garlic powder, splash of worchestershire sauce, 1/4 cup of merlot and 1 chopped onion and then cooked for around 6hrs.  I omitted the butter and found that you really don't need it. The flavor was fabulous!! This recipe is a keeper!

text:
I'm not quite sold on this. I filled the soup can with water because it looked ridiculously thick, and even after that it still came out VERY heavy, thick and pasty. I think less cream cheese, or perhaps replacing the cream cheese with sour cream. Had I made this recipe as directed (which I did right up the part where you add the soup and cream cheese) I would have given it 1 star. However, with the added water, I would have given it 3 stars. Both kids and my wife loved this and demanded that I put it on the menu again. They all said 5 stars, so I'm giving it four, as a sort of halfway thing. Mushrooms would make it better.

text:
I made this recipe for my dad & he absolutely loved it!  I thought it was a bit salty, but I figure that's from the can of cream of chicken soup.  I also took another reviewers suggestion & replaced the margarine with mushrooms & 1/2cup of water.  In addition, I used Neufchatel cream cheese & cooked it for an additional hour on low (instead of 30minutes on high).  In the end, I served it over whole wheat egg noodles - it was excellent & made for a wonderful lunch later in the week as well!  :)

I was excited about the recipe from the number of positive reviews and people who had saved the recipe.  Made as directed.  Served with egg noodles.  The taste combination was decent and my two year old ate it, however, the texture was gluey and thick...like a sauce that had Elmer's glue in it.  Removed from My Recipes. I loved this!! So easy and was a favorite with everyone. I did make some modifications based off  the review suggestions: started with 4 frozen chicken breast, 1/3 cup of milk, cream of chicken & cream of mushroom. Cooked that for several hours on high, then chopped chicken, added 1/3 cup of regular cream cheese and 1/3 cup of sour cream. I boiled the noodles and mixed them into the crockpot after the crockpot mix was done! LOVED IT. Mom said this is a keeper!

text:
After reading the reviews, I decided to add the cream of chicken soup in the morning (since I wouldn't be home from work for 8 hours).  The chicken fell apart after cooking that long, but that wasn't a turn-off for me since I like shredded chicken.  I added the cream cheese when I got home from work. And I also added mushrooms, a shallot, and 3 cloves of garlic that I sauteed in olive oil and an additional half pack of dry Italian salad dressing.  I thought the dish was still just a bit bland, so I added the rest of that second packet of Italian dressing mix to the crock.  Even as we sat down to eat this, it still tasted bland to me!  Overall this was pretty ok.  Easy, hearty and filling but nothing truly special.

text:
This recipe was amazingly easy and tasty.  I didn't like the MSG and wheat flour in the condensed cream of chicken soup, so I used Progresso Broccoli, Potato and Cheese soup which is gluten and MSG free.  I also added a bag of fresh broccoli and a bag of fresh mushrooms and used butter instead of margarine.  Plus, I used twice as much of everything except for the chicken so the dish would be really saucy.  I served it over rice.

text:
I made this putting the cream of chicken soup, half a package of italian dressing mix and a bit of butter in with the frozen chicken breasts to cook 4-5 hours on low. The chicken fell apart and shredded very easily and smelled amazing. I then added the cream cheese and about 1/2 a cup sour cream 30 minutes before serving. Everyone loved it! The food was gone in no time and I've had multiple requests for the recipe. Next time I'm going to use the entire package of Italian dressing mix to kick the flavor up a notch. Great dish!

text:
Super easy and good but a little thick. I think I will try this again and add a little chicken broth. I followed the recipe except adding one additional can of soup since I needed it to serve 5.
Made this again and it wasn't too thick. 
I used 4 very large frozen chicken breasts. I put them in frozen, poured melted butter and then sprinkled 2 packets of dressing mix on. After cooking I removed the chicken and cut into squares (I also scooped out the white goo from the chicken cooking) mixed 2 packages cream cheese and 2 cans soup with the mixer, added it to the juices in the crockpot and stirred well and then put the chicken back in and cooked another 30-40 min.

Display Name:
Marian

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was super busy and needed to get something going as Tuesday nights we are all in and out of the house at different times.  I put one large turkey breast and two chicken breasts in the crockpot with the Italian dressing mix and two tablespoons of butter.  I let that cook on low for about 2 1/2 hours since the chicken breasts were frozen and I cubed them about 1 1/2 hours into cooking.  At that point I added 1 chopped onion and 1 can of roasted garlic cream of mushroom soup.  A half hour before serving I combined 4 oz. of cream cheese with another can of cream of mushroom soup and about 1/4 cup of milk (that's all I had left!).  I whisked before adding it in along with some peas and let it heat through before serving with mini-farfalle.  It was a huge hit and an unexpected one at that.  This was so easy to make and with the little changes I made, I think it might even work as filling for a pot pie.

text:
I should have listened to the other reviewers. I followed the recipe exactly. I got home when the chicken had cooked on low for 4 hours... It was burnt, charred, stuck to the bottom, hard as rock chunks and completely inedible. I still added the soup and cream cheese. The flavor of the sauce was delicious but the chicken you could not eat at all. I will make this again, but on the stove top. There is no reason at all why cubed chicken needs to slow cook for 5-6 hours...and if you do feel like doing so save your meal and add some liquid in the beginning!

I used "Zesty Italian" dressing mix, and I added the cream of chicken soup along with the chicken, butter, and dressing mix.  I also added a little milk to thin it out. I served over egg noodles.  This was the perfect meal for a cool evening!

This called for four servings, so I ended up modifying it for my husband and I. I also took some suggestions from fellow reviewers. country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe with whole frozen chicken breasts, lower sodium mushroom soup, butter, creme fraiche, and (accidentally) ranch dressing mix. The ranch led to a different flavor from the traditional stroganoff. It was good but we felt it was a little too salty. If you are looking for a little different spin on  stroganoff, try this recipe with ranch mix, but don't use the whole packet. I will try this again some time with the Italian mix. Also, if you choose to use frozen chicken, make sure to put some of the butter on the top of the chicken to keep it from drying out. Overall, it was a great, easy dinner!

text:
As written, it wasn't my favorite - too greasy.  However, I tried again and made some modifications to create a recipe more to my liking.  I added one clove of chopped garlic, one small choped onion and a TB of butter into the crockpot along with 1 cup of chicken broth and my chicken breasts (1 use around 1 lb and a half).  Then I cook on low in the slow cooker for around 4 hours, shred the chicken, add a can  of cream of chicken and mushroom soup and a block of neufchatel cheese and simmer for a bit longer in the crockpot.  We serve it mixed with egg noodles.  I also would add mushrooms if I could, but my husband and kids don't like them.

text:
This was delicious EXACTLY as written. Many previous reviewers didn't believe that it could be cooked with only butter for hours but it was amazing and the gravy becomes much thicker by only cooking it on high for the last half-hour. Don't change it!  I also tried this on the stove-top as I realized I hadn't prepared enough for the number of people coming over. I did things in the same order (chicken, butter & Ital mix first, then cream cheese/soup mixture) and it also turned out great, though the gravy wasn't quite as thick. I then mixed both batches together. This is a nice alternative if you forget to start it in time and still want to serve this delicious dish!

text:
I had my reservations about this initially, but it was delicious! I made it with cream of mushroom soup and low fat onion and chive cream cheese.  Like other reviewers, I added a few tbsp of white wine while the chicken was cooking.  The chicken came out flavorful and tender.  I served it over No Yolk egg noodles. Fabulous, and maybe even better on day 2!  It's a tad on the salty side, so don't add any salt.  It was also a bit thick for my taste, so I added a splash of milk to make it a little more creamy.

text:
I made this for an easy Sunday dinner. The chicken went straight from the freezer to the slow cooker, and actually the cream cheese was frozen too (I threw everything in at once). Set the crock pot to high for about 4 hours. I added a few twists of fresh ground pepper and about a 1/4 cup of sherry to the pot about 30 minutes before serving. Judging from the faint sucking sounds from my three children and requests for seconds, and then thirds, I would say it was a resounding success. Five stars for easy prep, and yummy results.

text:
Yummy.  Not haute cuisine, not anything that would make your eyes roll back, but tasty, simple food that is a snap to prepare.  Before church on Sunday, I put the chicken in the crock pot ) still semi-frozen, but thawed enough to make cubing easy) and all the other ingredients except the cream cheese and cooked on high.  After church, came home and mixed the cream cheese in and let it melt in and meld while the noodles boiled.  Lunch was ready quickly and was very satisfying!  We'll have this again and again!

text:
Loved this recipe.  This could be the best slow cooker recipe I ever tried.  I too was sceptical about cooking the chicken with no liuid.  But what happens is that the chicken gets browned on the outside instead of soggy like most slow cooker meats.  It makes all the difference.  I was tempted to try the chicken before I added the cream cheese and soup (I didn't).  I also put the chicken in frozen and it works fine when cooked for 8 hours on low.  It is rich as originally designed.  I might try a lower fat version next time as others have tried.

text:
I put whole chicken breasts in the slow cooker and shredded them before adding the cream cheese.  I used 1/2 neufchatel and 1/2 full fat cream cheese because it's what I had.  It was a little salty, but I didn't salt my egg noodles so it all evened out.  It was a little thick, but not too bad.  Next time, I will thin it with a little noodle liquid or chicken broth.  Easy and tasty.

text:
WOW!! This is VERY good and my husband kept raving about how good it was. I did add the soup at the start because by the time I start up the crockpot and get home from work 10hours have passed, and I knew that the chix wouldn't hold up that long for me. When I added the cream cheese I added a little bit of chix broth to help thin the mixture just a tiny bit. The nice thing about this recipe is I always have the ingredients on hand! Will definately make this again! It made 6 servings for my family.

text:
I couldn't believe how good this was, especially considering how easy it was to prepare.  I cut down the butter by half and cut the cream cheese by about 1/4...it was still amazing and I was able to save some fat and calories.  When I added the soup/cream cheese mixture, I also put in some chopped yellow onion, a couple cloves of rough chopped garlic and some chopped fresh asparagus.  It was wonderful, and I look forward to making it again!  Thanks for sharing such an unblievably easy, yet tasty recipe!  :)

text:
this is SO good! i used the whole packet of dry italian seasoning and condensed cream of mushroom (it's all i had). i love this recipe because i don't have to thaw the chicken - it works just as well on a couple frozen chicken breasts. our budget likes it more saucy, less meaty, and it tastes good anyway. i throw the cream cheese in as i'm cooking the pasta (we prefer it with penne) and sprinkle grated parmesan cheese over each plate. it couldn't be more simple!!

text:
I used lowfat cream cheese and 99% fat free cream of mushroom instead of the cream of chicken. (It was all I had.) It turned out great! The key to this recipe is making sure your chunks of chicken are large. Mine were too small, and by dinner time, a few of the chicken pieces were hard. (but still tasty) My husband ate til there was none left!

text:
Stellar.  I actually used 2-3X the chicken and doubled the sauce stuff.  I worried that there would be too little sauce from what other reviewers said and there was TONS of good sauce so who knows.  I added one chopped white onion, one package of sliced button mushrooms, and about 3/4 cups of dry white wine at the beginning, all of which I would highly recommend.  The mushrooms come out perfectly browned.  I also cooked the chicken for 3-4 hours whole then took it out and shredded it easily with a knife and fork.  It was good to get it wet all so many surfaces for awhile and I like the shredded texture more than cubed before ever cooked.  Easy and delicious and my husband worshiped it.

I have one caveat to this review, and that is that tossing the chicken with the Italian dressing mix is great and works very well.  If you stop there,  this is a great recipe.    I've just started cooking with my crock pot and made this recipe after reading all the positive reviews and was extremely disappointed. I think this is from the condensed chicken soup, which is a disagreeable flavor and texture on it's own.

text:
This was an absolute hit at my house! WE LOVED IT! I put4 frozen breasts in my crockpot along with the dressing mix and half the suggested butter.  I let it cook on low about 5 1/2 hrs and then I put the soup, about half the amount of cream cheese, and I added about a 1/2 -3/4 cup sour cream (I did'nt really measure I just put in what I thought would be about right) I then let that cook for about another 1/2 hour.  I served it over egg noodles with french bread.  AWESOME!!!  Will definately make again. Thanx!

text:
This is delicious!  I'm making it today for the fourth time.  Even my husband loves it and he hates my cooking!  I sub sour cream for cream cheese because I can't stand cream cheese, add diced onion and sliced mushrooms and extra pepper.  You know, today was the first day I actually READ the directions (oops)...I have always put the soup in at the beginning with whole boneless breasts and cooked it on high for  a few hours.  Then you don't have to shred the chicken, it just falls apart.  Yummy on cold nights and reheats great for lunch at work the next day(s)!

text:
This was really easy to throw together. I threw 4 frozen chicken breasts in the crock pot with the Italian seasoning. After 5-6 hours on low, I shred the chicken into chunks and threw in the cream cheese and the soup. I was worried I wouldn't have enough stroganoff so I threw in about 1/2c. sour cream and a can of cream of mushroom soup too. Like I said before, super easy and good, but not great. It tasted like a thicker version of chicken noodle soup, which I'm not a huge fan of. FYI- I would've had plenty with the original recipe. Its heavy and filling! Poured over egg noodles.

OH MY GOSH DOES THIS SMELL GOOD TO COME HOME TO!!!!  I could smell it outside my house.  This is an awesome recipe because you play with it in so many ways.  If you like this with homemade noodles or rice go for it.  I used an onion soup packet instead of the dressing mix.  You can add any veggies you would find ina pot pie like carrots, potatoes, etc than use krusteaz for a crust or pillsbury biscuits on top for chicken and dumplings...  the list goes on and on.  the idea of cooking the chicken alone for a roasted flavor is incredible and I will be doing this a LOT.  THANKS FOR THE RECIPE!!!

text:
I didnt have time to do this in a crockpot so here is what I done.  I baked the chicken in the oven for the required time- i think 30 minutes.  While the chicken was in the oven, I cooked on the stove- cream of mushroom- didnt have chicken; italian seasoning, added white wine- due to other comments; a little water; and the reduced cream cheese.  I added according to my taste so more wine it went.  Something about adding the white wine made this dish a winner.  I cut the chicken in little pieces and added it the sauce.  I simmered it until the sauce was creamy not chunky.  I used the whole wheat noodles and pored on top before I served.  Had broccoli and garlic bread and it was a hit!!!  Can't wait until I get home today for the left overs.  I am sure it will be better the next day.  Thanks for this recipe - this is definitely a WINNER!!!

text:
This stuff was awesome and easy to make. I did have to fight the impulse to add it all together in the crock in the morning but controlled it and waited till after work while cooking egg noodles to throw in cream cheese and soup. It was so smooth and creamy. My husband really liked it but both agreed that next time I would add mushrooms. For that matter you could easily add your favorite veggie at the end as well. It was very thick and I did cut that with about a cup of chicken broth stirred in at the end but it did not change the taste and it was still thick and creamy after. The recipe is rich so you tend to eat a little less (not a bad thing) but oh so tasty.

text:
I just made this tonight, and my whole family loved it.  I did alter a little to suit our tastes, I was worried that I wouldn't like too much italian seasoning, so I didn't use it all, but next time I will use the full packet.  I also used only 4 oz cream cheese, but just because my husband isn't a fan of it and I wasn't sure how much of that taste would come thru.  I left the chicken breasts whole, added the soup at the beginning, and shredded the chicken after cooking, then added the cream cheese.  Overall, this was a great, easy meal, and my family will definitely be eating it again.  I may try will the full 8oz cream cheese next time, just to see the difference in flavor.  The kids ate over rice, we ate over mashed potatoes, it was really great with both!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe came out great.  The only change I made was adding a 1/2 cup of white wine at the beginning along with the butter and seasonings.  However I didn’t cube the chicken as instructed.  Instead I shredded the chicken like many other people mentioned in their reviews.  But I guess I shredded it too much.  It looked like tuna fish by the time it was done with all the stirring that was necessary to blend the cream cheese and condensed soup.  But even through it didn't look to appealing, It still tasted awesome.  Next time I will cube or not shred at all and just let the chicken fall apart on its own.  Thanks for posting this recipe.

text:
I'd give this 5 stars, if I hadn't altered so much.  I started by adding a carton of chopped mushrooms & 1/2 of a chopped onion to the chicken step, altho still included the butter & packet of dressing seasoning, with an extra 2T chopped garlic & 1/2c chicken broth.  since I put the breasts in frozen (forgot to thaw, for cubing first), so I just shredded the meat when it was cooked through.  to the final step, I substituted reduced-fat versions of the cream cheese & cream of mushroom soup, and added about 3/4c fat free sour cream.  we used wheat egg noodles - and enjoyed every bite!  I'll definitely be making this one again, and will not feel guilty about having seconds!  next time, I'm omitting the butter & just adding a little more broth instead tho.

text:
A definite keeper! Everyone in my family loved it. I used 2 lbs of frozen chicken breast, combined that with 2 cans of Cream of mushroom soup (that's all I had in the pantry), 1/4 C of White cooking wine, 1/4 C of chicken broth, and the packet of italian seasoning. Let it cook in the crockpot for 6hrs and then added the block of cream cheese and 1/3 C of sour cream. Let it cook for another 30 min. The only thing I would change would be to cut back on the italian seasoning, maybe reduce it to 3/4 of the packet. The family still loved it as is, but I would cut back next time. I served this over pasta with homemade biscuits. The sauce is sooo good with biscuits! Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This was very Yummy! I made it in a crockpot. I melted the butter in crock added dressing mix, 1/4c. wine, then added frozen chicken, cooked for 3 hours on high. Stir once or twice. Then added the cream cheese, cream of mushroon soup, salt, pepper, garlic powder and dried onions. Cooked it on low for another 1 and 1/2 hours or till the cream cheese melted and mixed up good with the soup. Nice and creamy. Served it over baked potatoe's. Very very yummy! You gotta try this.

OK...I did this recipe based on the ratings and the number of reviews.  As busy as I was, I, who normally read all reviews and change the recipe accordingly, did not make any changes really.  I have an awesome recipe for stroganoff that calls for wine...SO...at the beginning added some white wine with the chicken and italian seasonings.  I also just threw in whole boneless chicken breasts that were frozen.  My husband came home before I did...and called with great reviews before I even finished the recipe!  My biggest critics..and complainers of my cooking...really liked it!  However, the 6 year old would not touch it!!!  8 year old liked it...18 year old and hubby loved it!  Those were my only changes and it was not bad at all!!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe, but I didn't have all of the ingredients on hand so I had to make a couple of substitions.  I cubed the chicken breast and put it in a ziploc bag with the italian dressing mix and some extra dried basil and oregano and put it in the fridge overnight.  The next day, I added the chicken, margarine and 1/4 cup of white wine to the crockpot and set it to low for 5 hours.  After 4.5 hours I sauteeed a package of sliced mushrooms and added it to the crockpot along with a container of chive cream cheese and 1/2 cup of pre-made onion dip. (I didn't have any creamed soup on hand).  I also added approx 1.5 cups of fresh broccoli and 1/4 cup of chopped sundried tomatoes and let it cook another 30 minutes.  Served it with angel hair pasta topped with fresh grated parmesan cheese. My family loved it.  I will make it again, likely as I did this time, but I will shorten the cooking time to 4 or 4.5 hours.

text:
OMG! This is the BEST recipe!  I would give it 10stars if I could!  My boyfriend loves this!  I also sent to a few friends and they rate it 5stars as well.  It is so convenient to put the chicken in frozen.  My only addition is that when you put in the cream cheese, I also add a package of fresh baby portabella mushrooms, then cook for the recommended 1/2 hour more.  It is delicious!  *UPDATE* I've made this 6 or 7 more times now!  So convenient for a weekday meal.  I've also 'lightened' it up a bit, omitting the butter, using reduced fat Cream of Mushroom soup, and using 1/2 block Fat Free Cream Cheese and 1/2 block of a third less fat Cream Cheese, served with whole wheat noodles.  Amazing!!!

Display Name:
Laurinda

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious. I am not a fan of condensed soup and have only used them twice in the last 10 years.  Yet, all of the reviews made me very intrigued and the recipe was so simple.  I made some small changes and it turned out pretty yummy.  I substituted Bittersweet Farms for the salad seasoning mix.  Bittersweet Farms does no sugar, no salt, no preservatives seasoning mixes that are delicious. I used their savory herbs mixed with their golden onion mix, tblp of each. I didn't want to open a bottle of wine, so added 1/4 cup of vermouth to the chicken at the beginnning.  Next time, I might add less, as the chicken did not brown like it was supposed to. I also did not use any margarine or butter (trying to control cholesteral and fat).  I sauteed (using spray oil in nonstick pan to cut down on fat) one chopped yellow onion, add to slow cooker. Then I sauteed one pound baby bella (or cremini or button) mushrooms) sliced thickly.  When finished at about 4.5 hours, I added the red fat cream cheese, red fat cream of chicken soup for the half hour on high as suggested.  At the end I added 1/2 cup of low fat sour cream to add tang for the Stroganoff as suggested by readers.  Perfect! When I said to my husband, do you want leftovers or turkey meatloaf tomorrow night....he said leftovers :)  YUM!

text:
I morphed the leftovers of this into another meal by adding a can of diced green chiles and making enchiladas suiza.  To make the stroganoff, I used frozen chicken breasts and instead of italian packet, I sprinkled (eyeballed) garlic powder, onion powder, lemon pepper and basil over the chicken, added 2 T butter and I couldn't resist adding a little liquid, so I also added about 1/3 c white wine.  After cooking for several hours, I added the cream cheese and healthy request cream of chicken soup but it needed something so I added about 1 tsp lemon pepper and 2 T lemon juice along with 1/2 c sour cream.  It wasn't bad...we had it over rice.

text:
I loved this recipe! I didn't realize it only needed to cook for 5-6 hrs when I put the chicken in the crockpot before I left for church and I was worried we would end up having to eat it for lunch. When we came home, the house smelled great and the chicken had a nice color to it. When I added the brick of cream cheese and one can of soup, I was worried it would taste too much like cream cheese. I was also worried that since I was going to try to keep it in the crockpot til dinnertime that it would thicken up too much or dry out, so I added another can of the soup and never turned the heat to high. It was wonderful! I cooked the noodles and threw them in with the soup for the last ten minutes or so. Everyone had seconds and it reheated well too. Thanks!

text:
This was really good, but I definetly had to modify it a bit.  The first time I made it I was pretty unsure about putting in the chicken with so little else with it, and I was right to be - if I hadn't added a two cans of the soup halfway through it definetly would have burned.  So I modified it based on a recipe I already had that was very similar but for beef.  I added three cans soup, a packet of Garlic and Herb mix rather than the Italian dressing mix (just because that's what I had on hand) and a cup of Sprite along with the chicken in the beginning.  I know the Sprite sounds weird but it turns out so good.  Then when I was about ready to serve it, I added in half a block of cream cheese and a little milk, and served it over egg noodles.  Maybe my crock pot cooks too hot or something, but the way the recipe was written I'd have to give it about 2 stars - once I modified it though it's worth 5 - my husband LOVES it.  If you have a larger crock pot like I do, definetly put everything in first!

text:
The first time I  made this, the flavor was really good, but something was wrong with the consistency. It was incredibly thick, more like a spread than a sauce, and I never figured out what was wrong. I was thinking about making it again and looked at the recipe, when I realized my blunder! I used too much cream cheese! I used almost twice as much as the recipe called for...no wonder it was so thick! I am definitely going to give this a try again, being careful to only use the called for amount of cream cheese this time!

Display Name:
Ruby0728

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good! I made some substitutions and additions. First, placed the chicken breasts (2 large frozen), Italian dressing mix, butter, 1 cup of mushrooms and a healthy splash of white wine in the slow cooker, cooked on low for 4 hours. Removed chicken, cubed it and placed back in slow cooker then added about a 1/2 cup of chicken stock and 1 can of Cream of Chicken with Mushroom soup to the mix, continued cooking on low for 2 hours. About 30 minutes before serving added 2 oz of softened cream cheese, 8 oz of sour cream, 2 tablespoons of chives and a small jar of pimientos. Served over egg noodles and it was fantastic. Paired with fresh green beans stirfried in bacon, onion and vinegar (topped with lemon pepper). Had leftovers for lunch today and it was even better. A great comfort meal and in this day and age....we need all of that we can get.  

PS. I used lowfat and reduced sodium products as I normally do (except butter). Doesn't take away any flavor only unneeded fat calories.

Muffin Mom N Garlic Girl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/623213.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This wasnt bad at all. I did modify it some though nothing to taste altering. I noticed a good amount of other reviews say that this was salty and the chicken was dry. I used fat free I cant believe its not butter spray in place of butter. I also added a whole can of low sodium chicken broth in the crock pot for the chicken to cook in the chicken was very moist. The ckicken I cooked the night before and stuck it inthe fridge so it only had to cook around 45 minutes the next day. I did have to add 2 tbs of flour to thicken it up at the end so next time I will use just a half of a can. I also used low fat cream cheese and low fat low sodium cream of chicken. I'm glad I did I can see how regular higer sodium would have made it to salty. Next time I will use 2 packet od italian dressing and the broth did seem to dilute the spices. I served this over noodles and added peas at the end (simply so my 2 year old didnt have them rolling all over her plate. My family including my inlaws quite enjoyed it and my mother in law asked me for the recipe. This was a perfect easy and quick meal before a soccer game. Next time I may add half white wine half broth to the crock pot next time to see how it changes the flavor.

Pretty good base recipe. I altered a bit, though. I added 1/4 cup white wine and used italian dressing in place of the dry dressing. I put all the ingredients in at once and added milk to thin it out as it was so thick.

Will make again, and add some onions and peas half an hour before serving.

Great easy recipe.  I read some of the other posts so I made some changes. First, I didn't cut the chicken breasts. I added 1/2 cup of white cooking wine, some crushed red pepper, fresh garlic, a package of sliced mushrooms which I sauteed and used lite cream cheese. I also didn't  read the instructions and put all the ingredients in at once.  The sauce was probably thinner than if I had added some of the ingredients later but we prefer it that way. I would definitely make it this way again.

text:
Very simple recipe. It is tasty, but very rich; I had to thin it out a bit with skim milk because it is very thick if you follow the recipe exactly. Next time I make it, I'll do a low fat version (which is what I originally intended), with low fat cream of chicken soup, low fat cream cheese, or neuchatel. I wanted to follow exactly the first time to see how it would turn out, and how I could improve upon it. Overall, it was pretty good. I used fettucine pasta instead of the suggested rice.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/404155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok so first let me admit that I very LOOSELY followed this recipe but it was a great base to my tasty creation. So heres what I did; I started with 2 b/l s/l ck breasts cut into bite size pieces. In a deep skillet I added 2T butter, 1/4 chopped onions, 2T garlic and the chicken. I browned the chicken and set aside. With the skillet still hot I added enough chicken broth to remove the ck bits then added the crm of ck soup ,4oz of cream chz & 1/2 pack of Italian dressing mix then reduced the heat to low-med (4 on an electric stove) and simmered. I added 1 pkg of spinach and simmered for a total of 15min (Stir often). I served over egg noodles. It was GREAT!!

WOW - How easy was that!  I did it a little different to make it go a little further, per my sister's advice.  I just cooked the chicken as stated, before adding other ingredients, I removed chicken, shredded it with 2 forks and removed any fat that was still on it.  After I added the other ingredients to the slow cooker and mixed them up well, I stirred the shredded chicken back into the mix. I also added my cooked bow tie pasta at the same time. So very yummy.  Thank you for sharing.

text:
I saw this recipe today and tried it today. I followed the recipe except I added a chopped onion, a can of condensed Cream of Mushroom soup and 1/4 can of water because the sauce was really thick. I also only used 1/2 of the cream cheese. It's seasoned nicely, not salty. And once the chicken began to cook (with just the dry seasoning and margarine), it generated its own juices. I cut short the cooking time because the chicken began to shred (which really isn't a bad thing). I served it over pasta and my children enjoyed it. It's not the most attractive dish in the world, but it's good.

text:
Oh my heavans - this is sooo good!  Not for the calorie conscience, but yum!  I pretty much followed the recipe, except I experimented by leaving 2 breasts whole and cutting 2 into large cubes. Both ways came out fine. I also used 3 TBS of butter instead of 2 b/c my chicken breasts were quite large. I ended up removing much of the melted butter before adding the soup and cream cheese. The sauce is a little thick, so I think next time I might try to add some milk or something to thin it out a bit. Served over bow-tie and wagonwheel pasta (I was using up two partial boxes).

5 stars and then some.  This was so good.  My kids gave it 5 stars too.  I did make a few changes though based on what I had on hand.  I also decided to add a little liquid while cooking the chicken as I noticed it looked like it was getting dry quickly. Here are my changes/additions: - added @ 1/2 cup chicken broth with chicken and butter - used a packet of stroganoff mix in place of italian dressing - added another @ 1/2 cup chicken broth after chicken was cooked - used reduced fat cream cheese Turned out great!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3566572.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe!  I took the suggestion of another reviewer and  omitted the cream cheese for an 8 oz container of lite garlic and herb cheese spread (like Alouette, but the off-brand). I was worried that the combination of that and the italian seasonings might be too much, but quite to the contrary, the flavors were just right.  My chicken was thawed when I put it in, and cooking time really maxed out at 3 hrs on high.  Served over brown rice is delicious, but I think I might try wild rice next time.  Some people talked about the chicken overdrying.  Two things: don't use any more than 1.5 lbs of chicken, and make sure the sauce coats the chicken very well while cooking.  (Of course, don't overcook.) I'll be making this again for sure!

country:
None
text:
This recipe was definitely edible, but  I will cut down on the cream cheese next time.  I used a splash of white wine in the beginning as others did, and also  substituted the cream of chicken with cream of mushroom.  Next time, I plan to use about 1 part cream cheese and three parts sour cream, to avoid the overly sweet taste I found using all cream cheese.  Like other though, I did like the way the chicken roasted, due to the lack of moisture at the start.  Pretty good stuff.

this recipe was good but as others have said it is VERY salty...and we love salt but it was even a little much for us!  I put in an extra can of soup and there still could have been more sauce for my liking.  my 7 year old son would have eaten it all if we had let him it was a hit with him!  I'll probably make it again but try to cut down the salt at least a bit.

**Update: My husband took the leftovers to work the next day and he said they were even better, we just tossed the stroganoff over the pasta in a container so it was all warmed together...next time I'll toss the cooked noodles into the stroganoff the last 30 minutes or so.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm really rating the recipe with the  modifications suggested by other reviewers. I omitted the butter. In the crock pot I put one can of low sodium low fat cream of chicken soup, one envelope of Italian dressing mix, garlic powder, salt and pepper, onion, white wine, 1/2 can worth of water, and 3.25 lbs skinless chicken thighs. After the chicken was cooked I added only 4oz of cream cheese. After tasting this, I agree with other reviewers that 4oz is plenty and adding more would not be good. The resulting dish was very tasty and the chicken was moist and so tender it fell off the bones. I served this over noodles as suggested, but DH thought it would also be nice with mashed potatoes so I think I'll try it that way next time. Thanks for a nice recipe.

text:
The chicken was moist and delicious and the packet of Italian seasoning was very good - I didn't feel like the recipe needed any more seasoning. However, the addition of the cream cheese made it too thick and it just felt like we were eating cream cheese and butter on noodles. 

If I ever make it again, I'll substitute the cream cheese with a cream that's not quite as a thick or calorie dense as cream cheese and I'll probably do mushrooms instead of butter, like some of the other commenters.

It is great! FYI, I didn’t have 4 hours to slow cook so I put it on high for 1 hour with the chicken cubed, butter & Italian mix and it cooked up perfect! Then I added the soup and cream cheese on low for a half hour and it was great. So if you don’t have the time, try it on high! Just as good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is what it's meant to be.  An easy dinner idea. It tastes great but use the zero salt COC soup. Also, and this is crucial to any slow cooker recipe,  take the few extra minutes to sear the chicken with  med high heat and a little oil. DON'T  cut the cubes too small and go ahead and get that brown caramelisation on the chicken first. Deglaze the pan with a little h2o, or chicken broth ( better ) and pour that in too. Never put raw meat of any kind in a slow cooker.  Trust me it is Soooooo much better that way and it takes only a few extra minutes.

userID:
4822028
Display Name:
Howard Huggins
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
59
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/510904.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a VERY simple to make meal and it tastes GREAT, But.........

Adding 0.7 Oz (!!) package of Italian salad dressing (dry) was/is FAR too much IMHO!!
"Maybe" 0.25 Oz UNLES you desire a REALLY Italian flavored dish. 
I'm hoping the recipe was a misprint for the quantity of the dry dressing, personally, but I am thankful I LIKE the flavoring, even with the excessive amount. 
Lastly, this is a somewhat bland recipe as is. No real spices tasted outside of the excess Italian dressing, IMO. 
I dressed mine up with a few big scoops of sour cream to give it a creamier texture, too.
Lastly, I HIGHLY suggest you NOT overwork the meat while blending and incorporating the soup and cream cheese. 
Doing so pretty much shreds the meat which is not typical of a "Stroganoff" meal. If you think about it, typical Beef Stroganoff has CHUNKS of meat throughout but if you aren't careful here, you'll have a shredded chicken Stroganoff-like meal over noodles. While tasty, the appeal will be lacking and more like a gruel instead of a classy meal. 
Using the changes I've implemented and (perhaps) some of other contributors, I can see myself making this again. It is a simple meal you toss on the crockpot (slow cooker) after Sunday morning breakfast, walk away for 4-6 hours depending on your slow cooker, and enjoy the enticing aromas throughout your home right up until dinner time. 
What a truly easy, tasty, filling, and enjoyable meal for a family and/or friends.
Paired with a loaf of sliced Fren
Review:

text:
Loved this recipe! Well I’m not the type to follow a recipe to the tee but here’s what i did: used a big package of chicken that needed using out of the freezer (so it was all going in regardless). Had a can of fat free cream of chicken soup in the cabinet that was accidentally purchased (I usually don’t buy the fat free)-so to use that up this was perfect. Used regular cream cheese. Added some shakes of garlic salt and ground pepper. After done cooking decided to toss a handful of sharp shredded cheese. A little rich on its own but still really good. Wanted to add some easy veggies so I dumped in my bowl a big scoop of mixed veggies (peas, carrots, g beans and corn frozen bag mix). Mixed it all up with some pasta I also found in the cabinet and viola! My 2 year old also loved it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We ended up really liking this recipe but only after making quite a few changes. I added a few portabella mushrooms, a 1/4 a cup of Worcestershire sauce, and about 6oz of beer (I used Miller, PBR would also be fine.) Without these additions, I have no idea how this recipe can be considered a "stroganoff." Without them, this recipe is still good but just tastes like any other chicken casserole. If you are making this dish, I highly recommend adding one or more of these ingredients, especially if you want your meal to actually resemble a stroganoff.

text:
So of course, I added garlic salt, basil, and thyme, as seasoning is always subjective and to taste. I used a full stick of salted butter in the initial cooking, and ended up adding two cans of cream of mushroom soup and a can of mushroom stems and pieces. Finally, I added my wide egg noodles and added water and chicken broth as needed so as to not allow it to get overly thick to the point of burnt, as the pot would sit another six hours before being enjoyed.

region:

country:
None
text:
Not the most complex flavors, but still a very flavorful dish. I made this for my lunches while meal prepping for the week.

Made a few small changes:
-Used chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts
-Included mushrooms
-Because of the addition of the mushrooms, I was worried that there wasn't enough liquid in the pot for the first 6 hours, so I used an extra tablespoon of butter

A few additional notes for myself:
-I used Good Seasons Zesty Italian dressing.
-I kept the heat on low for another 1.5 hours after adding in the rest of the ingredients, rather than crank it up to high for a half hour. This worked fine.

Add in some rice and you've got a lunch that is creamy and cheesy, but surprisingly not too heavy.

userID:
5102873
Display Name:
phillythekid
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A delicious recipe that clearly warrants leftovers. I tripled the recipe to feed a few extra folks and rolled the dice on having leftovers....WORTH IT! The flavor was awesome as is though in order to provide more 'substance' to it I diced 1 each medium green, red and orange peppers and 1 medium onion and sautéed them while cutting up the chicken. Since tripling the recipe I wanted to ensure the chicken would cook evenly so I partially cooked it in batches with the dried Italian dressing mix. When finished this step I added the margarine to the slow cooker and layered the chicken and pepper/onion mix then topped with the remaining 1/2 pack of dressing mix. The slow cooker was on high (4 hour). At about the 2 hour point I placed 2 packs of cream cheese on the slow cooker lid to soften it. At the 30 minute point I  mixed 2 cans of soup and 1 1/2 packs of cream cheese and stirred it into the crock. It was still pretty 'watery' so with about 10 minutes left I mixed 3 TS of corn starch with a couple TS of water and stirred it into the crock. 10 minutes later it was perfect. Again, a delicious meal.

After reading a lot of reviews, I added finely chopped onion, finely chopped mushroom (I have picky 6 and 8 yr olds and if they see anything of color or unknown shape they will not even try it). I also added a little garlic powder.  I have never left a review before, but my son loved this so much I had to. This is beyond amazing in my house. My 8 year old likes hot dogs, pancakes, waffles, chicken strips, and plain dry hamburgers. That's it. So yeah this warrants a 5 star!!!! If I was making it again, for just adults, I would have added fresh garlic, and probably pepper. But for picky eaters, this was absolutely perfect.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my 2nd time making this dish, and I did a few things differently. I took the chicken breasts and tenderized them before cutting them into cubes. I put them into the slow cooker. I used 1/4 C melted butter instead of 1/8 C, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1 tsp salt and added the packet of Good Seasons Italian seasoning, mixing well. I poured it over the chicken and cooked as directed for 5 hours. I then softened the cream cheese, mixed it in the cream of chicken soup and poured over the chicken. Cooked for another 30 minutes. Served over egg noodles. The scallions shown in the picture weren't part of the recipe, but I chopped up about 1/2 cup of them and sprinkled over the dish after removing from the slow cooker. Much better taste in my opinion. Thanks to Judi Ann for the base recipe!

text:
Based on other reviews, I halved the cream cheese. I probably shouldn't have, as it wasn't quite "saucy" enough after I added a full bag of cooked wide egg noodles. After adding the noodles, I stretched the sauce by adding a splash each of chicken stock and milk, and approx. 1/3 cup of sour cream. Delicious! Otherwise, I followed the recipe as written. I also sauteed some sliced mushrooms and sprinkled them on top of the stroganoff/pasta after plating (not everyone in my family likes mushrooms, or I would have added them to the sauce). This recipe is a keeper!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice so far. The first time, I added onions and mushrooms. I had also added a 1/2 cup of chicken broth at the beginning because I used frozen chicken. The sauce came out a little soupier than I wanted.

The second time I did this, I used thawed, cubed chicken, followed the recipe exactly as written, and it came out perfect.  I did add chopped onions with the chicken, and I melted the butter before adding it with the Italian dressing mix. With that, I used the whole packet. I added frozen mixed veggies in with the cream cheese and canned soup. If you're really in a hurry, you can add partially cooked noodles during the last 30 minutes of cooking as well.

I liked the recipe as is, and unlike others, the dish didn't taste salty to me. But I learned that everyone has their own level of saltiness that they can tolerate. My family also enjoyed this recipe as well. It's been printed out and added to my homemade cookbook.

text:
This is my favorite recipe I've found on here! It was so easy but yet so delicious! It's only 5 ingredients and the only prep is cutting the chicken. My rice cooker/slow cooker only has a "high" setting, so the chicken/margarine/seasoning mixture was done in 3 hours and 45mins. I pulled the chicken apart just a little with a spatula before adding the cream cheese and soup then kept it on high for 30 minutes stirring occasionally. Served over egg noodles. It was so delicious and filling. My boyfriend and mom loved it as well. The best part is it is just as great as leftovers. I'm very pleased! Thank you for this great recipe.

text:
This was really tasty - but I made changes so the rating is based on what I did.  I used the Italian Dressing Mix (found on this site) - about 1/3 of the dry ingredients that recipe calls for - to season 4 chicken breast halves.  Turns out that was a lot of chicken so after it cooked I removed about half of it to use another time.  I added low fat cream cheese and lower sodium cream of mushroom soup and a little milk.   I also sauteed some crimini mushrooms and added those.  We really liked it over rice.

text:
The wife says it's a keeper. I agree. Although I made a couple changes, I stayed with the recipe basics. I didn't have the dry dressing ingredient so I  put the chicken chunks in a Zip-Lock bag along with about 3 T of Italian dressing (out of the bottle) and marinated overnight. In the morning I melted the butter in the cooker, then added the chicken along with 1/2 C chopped onion. I also added a half cup of wild mushrooms simply because they were leftovers. I followed the cooking instructions as given along with the late soup addition. Served over noodles. Delish.

This is a super easy, satisfying dinned that I'll make again and again. I added a couple larges splashes of white wine to the pot at the beginning and otherwise followed as directed. We didn't think it was too salty at all (and my husband is sensitive to that), nor too thick. Tastes a lot like the chicken tetrazini my mom used to make when served over noodles, but a lot easier to make! In that vein, the second time I made it I added peas and mushrooms I had sauteed in white wine. Definitely a keeper!

text:
I added about a cup of sliced mushrooms at the beginning, and cooked on high for 2 1/2 hrs. because I got a late start. After 2 1/2 hrs. I tossed in the cream cheese and soup- I also substituted cream of chicken/mushroom, put the lid back on turned it to warm. After 15 minutes (which I used to cook some wide egg noodles)everything stirred/blended together  beautifully with little effort. It was really  tasty, everyone enjoyed it. Someone said it was horribly salty? I'm wondering if they  served it with ricearoni or flavored noodles or something, because with the plain noodles(and I would assume plain rice), it was not overly salty. I will make it again.

text:
I LOVE SALT...and this recipe has plenty of it. 
All kidding aside this is a very good recipe. But there is a lot of salt, no way around it. Not too much in my opinion, but it's there. I personally believe the salt comes from the dry salad dressing packet. I could be wrong but any time I use a recipe with any type of dressing packet, it tends to be salty. I would suggest a reduced sodium condensed chicken as well. I would also include a veggie side (I used broccoli) with wide egg noodles, all of which diluted the salt taste. Will definitely make again.

I really liked this.  Am always looking for recipes for my 91 year old mother who looks at most recipes and says "too many ingredients".  She even makes it. The next time I made it I wanted more sauce so I doubled the soup (used both cream of chicken and Cream of Chicken and mushroom).  I also sauteed some button mushrooms and added them.  If you double the soups, don't forget to double the italian dressing to keep the flavor up.

region:

country:
None
text:
Could NOT be easier and an absolute hit with the family.  I made the WHOLE BAG of egg noodles to top with this; as I speak, they are finishing it ALL off for late-night snacks after dinner!

My additions were simple:  a shake of garlic powder (NOT garlic salt), dried onions, mushrooms, and what I had left of a container of sour cream (probably about a generous 1/3 cup). Oh, and I substituted cream of mushroom for cream of chicken soup.

I've never been one to have a "rotation" of recipes for the week, but this one will likely be the one that starts my list!  And I would not hesitate to serve it to company with a nice salad and dinner rolls.

text:
I finally found a chicken recipe for the crock pot!  I made the recipe as-is and thought it was a little thick at the end so I added some milk to get the consistency we like.  But the chicken does not need liquid initially; it browns nicely and was really tender.  I did put the chicken chunks in partially frozen because I was worried about it being dry.  Cooked on low about 7 hrs. Easy, yummy meal for the working parent!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious and oh-so-easy.  I made some changes but can still reliably rate this recipe.  

My changes were to use butter instead of margarine, chicken thighs instead of breasts and I overcooked it by several hours since hubby had to work late (which I wouldn't recommend  lol! but it was still delicious!  Using chicken thighs meant I didn't end up with dried-out chicken, it was just completely shredded...no longer cubed.).  I added mushrooms about 1 hour before serving (about 30 minutes before adding the soup and cream cheese) mainly because I didn't have any chicken cubes anymore so the mushrooms gave it a "chunkiness" that I wanted.

When I added the cream cheese I stirred the whole mixture until the cream cheese completely melted, then I added the cream of chicken soup.  I served it over egg noodles.  Hubby said "it's a keeper".  

Great recipe, comfort food at its best.  I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I rate this a 4 because it is a great base recipe for a slow cooker. LOTS of room for tweaking. Since it had so many reviews as is, I wanted to give my variation.
I used 8 bone-in chicken thighs instead of cut up chicken breast. Same amount of time on low. 
I pulled the chicken out and shredded it then put it back in the juices with the listed ingredients but also added sliced mushrooms and frozen peas. 
Cooked in slow cooker for another hour then added cooked egg noodles, mixed, added some shaved Parmesan cheese on top and baked in a 350 degree oven for 25 more minutes.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3720453.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definitely a keeper in my family. I did it a little differently though. Instead of using dry Italian dressing mix, I just cubed the chicken and threw it in a Ziploc baggie. Then I poured in a good Italian dressing (I happened to have Olive Garden Signature Italian Dressing that I had bought at Sam's Club (but you can buy in other stores too.) and mushed it around a bit and let it sit for about 15 minutes or so. Then I poured everything into the crock pot with the butter. Instead of just 1/8 cup margarine, I used 1/2 cup butter (I'm German so I'm a butter lover). Also, when I added in the cream cheese and soup, I added in a bunch of frozen broccoli just for a veggie serving and a little color.  It wasn't too salty or anything. It was definitely different and my picky 5-year-old ate it quickly without a fuss!

text:
I didn't have high expectations of this simple recipe, but my hubs and I were pleasantly surprised how delicious it was. I followed the recipe pretty closely except that I added a chopped onion to the crock pot at the start of cooking (only because when I threw my frozen chicken breasts in the pot I wasn't sure what I was making yet, hehe)... and I used only half a brick of cream cheese because that's all I had -- but added a few big spoonfuls of sour cream to compensate.  I also added a healthy dash of milk to thin it out a bit and make more sauce to cover the fettuccine noodles I served it on.  Finished it off with a little chopped parsley and plenty of fresh-ground pepper which made it taste more stroganoff-like and balanced out the saltiness. So good we both had seconds.

This is my "go-to" recipe for when I can't think of anything else yummy to cook for my wife.

I did the first step exactly how it was stated. I slow-cooked the chicken for 4 hours in the italian dressing mix. I liked that the chicken was pulling apart after 4 hours and was lightly browned. I then added a bullion cube because it was lacking salt. I then proceeded to add the cream of chicken soup, some mushrooms and the cream cheese. After adding the soup and the cream cheese, the dish became very bland. It took away all of the flavor. I had to modify this dish by adding garlic powder and more seasonings. Overall, ok dish but needs more spices.

Many reviewers changed the steps and ingredients so I really hesitated following the original recipe. My only suggestion for next time (and there will be a next time). Is to soften the cream cheese in the microwave before adding it to the crockpot. LOVED IT!!! And all 3 of my kids loved it, too, which is a pretty big feat. I did make changes as suggested by other reviewers: I added 1can reduced sodium cream of CELERY soup, 1/4 cup white wine, 1/4 cup milk, 1/4 cup butter, and 3 frozen chicken breasts. I also misread the recipe and added 1/2 packet RANCH dressing instead of Italian. It still turned out great! After 5 hours the chicken just fell apart. I shredded it, then added the Neufchâtel cheese and some Sriracha (my family likes a little spice). I added some sautéed Baby Bella mushrooms and it was perfect! I will definitely make this one again. Thank you!!

text:
I added a touch more margarine.  Added an onion, about 8oz of mushrooms, 6oz of peas, and 6oz of cut carrots.  I doubled the cream cheese and soup for the extra volume.  Added 8oz of sour cream too.  The soup was low sodium and the cream cheese and sour cream were low fat.
Cooked step one on low for 5 hours.
Added onion, carrots.
Cooked for another hour.
Added mushrooms and frozen peas.
Cooked for another hour.
Added everything else.
One more hour.

Tastes amazing.  Served over egg noodles.  Will totally cook this up again.

text:
I made it as is to start, but thought it didn't have much to tie the cream cheese and the soup flavors together.  It was also much too thick to put over noodles.  So I added some milk until it was more creamy/saucy and some Worcestershire to taste and added some fresh cracked pepper.  The Worcestershire really tied the flavors and made it taste pretty good.  My 6 year old really liked it as well.  Hubby didn't say much, so to me that means it was probably edible to him but he'll probably request I don't make it again.  But then, he isn't a big "white sauce" person.

text:
What a yummy recipe, thank you, Judi Ann!!  I wasn't sure if it would all come together but it really did!  It was so creamy and yummy.  The only modification I made to the recipe was including butter instead of margarine. I would definitely add this to our routine, not weekly because it's made of cream soup and cream cheese, but definitely monthly and for guests!  The only thing that was strange about it was that the cream cheese never completely melted in despite the fact that I cooked it for about 7 - 8 hours on high. I did put it in cold right from the refrigerator in big chunks but I thought that with enough time in the slow cooker on high (about 1 1/2 hours) it would melt completely from the heat.  Regardless of the little visible pieces of cream cheese, it was delicious : )

text:
I'm actually surprised by how delicious this is because I'm not exactly a 'good cook'... I doubled the recipe & used 1 can of cream of mushroom and 1 can of cream of chicken. Although, I still used 1/2 the amount of cream cheese I should have. Instead of cooking the chicken as cubes, I cooked them as they were half cutlets and then shredded them just before adding the soup & cream cheese. I also added frozen broccoli in at the beginning so it mushed into the sauce, which I prefer. My boyfriend & sister are the 2 pickiest eaters I know and they loved it! I'm sure this would be a hit for kids too.

userID:
14498009
Display Name:
Firstname Lastname
isPro:

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1576140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe didn't make sense to me when I read it.  Where was the liquid?  Just chicken and 1/2 cup wine in the crockpot - for SIX hours?  Sure enough, it started to burn at 5 1/2 hours.  I added the cream cheese and soup mixture, but it was still too thick.  The directions don't say if you're supposed to add the can of water to the soup mixture...so I'm thinking there should be at least half a can.  That didn't occur to me at the time, and since I know real Stroganoff uses sour cream, I added about half a cup of sour cream.  Also, I added a pound of sliced mushrooms.  Also, I don't get slow cooking something for six hours.  For me, the whole point of using a crockpot is I can put the meal on before work, and it's ready after work (so 8 - 10 hours).  I'm not working right now, but if I was - I couldn't have tried this recipe on a work day.  Also, slow cooking chicken cubes for that long did not make it succulent and tender.  To me, it made it taste like canned chicken.  This is easier than a real Stroganoff and I learned about dry Italian seasoning mix, so with the modifications I made, we all liked it and I'll be making my version again.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Made this using Healthy Request cream of chicken and cream of mushroom soups. I added the whole chicken breasts (half-frozen), dressing, and soups to the crock-pot, and cooked on HIGH for 3 hours. I then shredded the chicken, added 4oz. each low-fat cream cheese and sour cream, and let it cook for another 30 minutes. Served it over egg noodles, with steamed broccoli. My family loved it.
